He had been voted through to the semis on a knife's edge, then lost out to a choir in coordinated blue, because a choir is what Sundays love.

He checked his phone only when his mother sighed theatrically. The message was there. It had the subject line with more caps than civilised people use.

RAF, CALL US WHEN YOU CAN. URGENT.

He looked at the word RAF and at the sender's name, which, to his tired eyes, looked like a misinterpretation of his own name. He wiped his thumb on his shorts, just in case his skin could smudge the meaning.

“What?” Maya said, catching the change in his posture.

“It’s from the show,” he said.

“What show?”

“The show,” he said, and then he laughed at himself for how he didn't say the name as though it were some old superstition, like not whistling in the house. He pressed the call button. His heart had brought a drum into his chest without consulting him. As it rang, he saw himself, absurdly, reflected in the kettle’s chrome, and he was small and full of steam.

“Rafi? Hi, it’s Rosanna from production,” the voice said. Bright, clipped, with a tiredness well hidden but there if your ear was trained for it.

“Yes,” he said, and tasted salt where the air had cracked his lips.

“Can you talk?” she asked in that way that sounds like a test more than a question.

“Yes,” he repeated. He glanced at his mother, who had put down her spoon and was leaning into the phone from across the room as if proximity could translate into understanding.

“We’re going to be bringing you back,” Rosanna said. “For the final. There's been discussion, you know, lively, about wildcards. We wanted the ideas to be broader this year, not just singing and the usual, and your piece caught fire online after your semi-final. Not to make your head explode, but two million views and a lot of comments about the way you—” she paused, possibly looking for a word that wasn't “looked sweaty.” “The way you told a story. We would love you to come back.”

The kettle had boiled, then the click of it suddenly was like a punctuation mark he wanted to underline. Rafi did not speak right away. He had made himself a rule when he was younger: never believe good news on the first read. It was born of counting times that initial elation had gone the way of sugar in tea, gone grain by grain with stirring.

“For the final,” he said.

“Yes. We know it’s short notice. There’s a wrinkle: we'll need you to work on a version that suits the live finale stage— bigger, different shapes, fire regulations, you know. We can help you with the design. But—” she must have heard something in the silence “—if you're worried about what's involved, we can walk it through. We'd like to lock this by this evening.”

“My mum’s listening,” he said, and regretted it immediately like a child who confesses to a teacher that his mother is in the audience.

“Say hi to Mum,” Rosanna said, unfazed. “Congratulations. Everyone in our office is really excited to have you. And, Rafi? There's another bit. The union can handle a per diem, and we'll put you up. Do you have a manager, anyone we should be liaising with?”

He laughed. It came out unexpectedly high. “No,” he said. “No manager. Just me.”

“Okay. I'll send a contract and a schedule. I have to jump, but call me when you've read it. Welcome back.”

They went through the usual phone polite and then he hung up and looked at his mother. Her hands had gone to her mouth even though she did not yet know what to say. She came up out of her chair faster than Rafi had seen her move in weeks.

“The final,” he said. “They want me.”

She hugged him. She smelled of soap and the faintest shadow of perfume she had worn in 1992. He held her as if, somehow, he was keeping the piece of good news from blowing out the open window.

When his father called, as if some secret village telegraph had rung him, Rafi had to leave the room because the kitchen could not hold both that voice and his own surprise. He took his phone into the hallway where the floorboards had curves like someone had stored waves there. “Kid,” his father said, a name he used regardless of age. “Amanda Holden will be talking about our name.”

“It’s just a show,” Rafi said, which was what he was meant to say. It is never just a show. His father had an almost religious belief in the power of British television to hand out miracles once a week. People were always winning money or proposing to each other or finding a lost cousin in a cupboard. “I still have to go.”

“And we will be watching,” his father said. “Your aunty in Luton already knows. Don't ask how.”

When he went to work at the shop, he told no one. In the mirror of the staff toilet he tried to practice the shrug he would use when people asked. He couldn't get it right. His own face kept giving him away. He stacked shelves of cereal with an earnestness his boss, Vince, called "religious", and he forgot the prices of things he'd known for months, and at one point he lined up six jam jars in a row like trophies.

In the afternoon, Leah came in. He had known she would. They had a text language of ellipses and gifs that said more than calling did. She was wearing the red beanie that made her look like a cartoon burglar. She was carrying her bike helmet in her left hand and two croissants in her right, as if she had crashed a French breakfast.

“You're famous,” she whispered across the fruit aisle, but the whisper turned cartwheely.

“Don’t,” he said, but smiling.

“Final,” she said. “Final. Do you know what that means? We have to make a thing. We have to go big. Are you going to jump off a car? Can you do that? No, that's not legal. What if we played with the light more? That first bit where your shadow looks like it leaves you—”

He put a finger to his lips. “I'm in a shop,” he said to remind her, as if the stacks of tins weren't evidence enough. “Don't get me fired on the day this happened.”

“Vince will forgive you,” she said, and then Vince materialised with a trolley and said, “Forgive him for what?”

“Nothing,” Rafi said, and dropped a packet of spaghetti that then exploded into its life in the aisle.

“Nothing?” Vince said, sweeping a hand over the mess in a generous imitation of an Italian man in films. “This spaghetti survived a factory and a lorry and one very bored teenager lifting it, and you, Rafi, have defeated it.”

Leah snorted into her croissant. “I’m going to cry,” she said, which made Vince blink twice as if he had stumbled into a theatre he hadn’t paid for. She turned toward the door, then back again. She caught Rafi's eye and mouthed: tonight? The videos? He nodded. She raised her croissant like a baton, then left in a gust of cool air and tiny flakes of pastry that were too light to get in trouble.

Rosanna's email arrived at four. He read it on his phone in the stockroom, perched on a crate of toilet rolls like a scholar reading a letter from a long-dead poet. The schedule was both a military operation and a suggestion. Rehearsal slots. Camera rehearsals. A health and safety session which, he noted, was bolded. A meal plan. He liked to cook his own, he always had, but there was a line item that read: canteen access available, dietary requirements to be logged, contact Yvonne. The contract was in PDF. He downloaded it and saw his name spelled correctly four times and once as Rafl. He forgave them. He sent it to Leah. He sent it to his father, who replied with eight clapping hands, four fire emojis, then “what does this part mean,” beneath a clause about exclusivity periods.

When his shift ended, he walked home slower than he had run that morning. The light was yellow and then it remembered winter was not yet done and went grey again. He could feel the house pulling him like a magnet. He liked to arrive at his kitchen with sweat and leave it to his mother to make a small fuss; he liked to be someone's good thing at the end of a day. He would be away now. He thought of his mother folding him into a large city in her quiet mind and trying not to worry.

They ate dinner at the narrow table; he cooked. He made dal with the lentils his aunt had sent from Pakistan because she believed England did not grow proper lentils. He made rice and added cardamom pods he’d learned, only last year, change everything. He chopped spinach and let it sag into the pan with the slowly contented sound of something coming to itself. His mother set the plates with that mixture of ceremony and practicality she inherited from her own mother: you feed someone as if the day has been hard. She listened to him talk about the schedule and asked questions for the sake of having him tell her everything twice.

“You'll have to eat,” she said.

“I always eat,” he said.

“You'll have to be careful,” she added, looking at him in that layered way that mothers look— seeing his future, seeing his earlier baby self and the teenager who refused to drink milk for a year. “Remember Manchester? That girl's chicken salad?”

“It was tuna,” he said. It had not been tuna. He had eaten something and had been sick for thirty hours and had promised himself sternly that he would never leave himself at the mercy of a backstage canteen again, that he would bring jars and Tupperware and utensils. He had a tiny stove he took when he travelled, the kind backpackers use. He had felt ridiculous the first time he'd boiled rice in a hotel room mug, then utterly vindicated when the others had eaten grey pasta at midnight and regretted living at three.

“I'll be careful,” he said.

After dinner, Leah came with her laptop and their rehearsal footage. Their rehearsal space was the allotment car park after dark. That was the truth of it. He had learned to imagine the chalk lines on the asphalt into a stage. He had taught his body to believe in invisible walls. Leah filmed with a steady hand. They watched the clips and stopped them where his foot had landed early or where the cut gave the wrong angle to the move where he vaulted and let the audience think he would not make the second step but then did.

“There,” Leah said and tapped the screen. “That. Keep that.”

“That” was small. It was the way his shoulders softened and then rolled forward before he pivoted, like a secret door in a crowded room. He had not known it would play like that until he saw it now. He tried to pretend not to smile, failed, then smiled at his failure and the room warmed.

“Big stage,” Leah said. “You could put a ladder that rises, like it shouldn't, in a way. Or people. Two people, moving obstacles. That will be the trick: get the audience to feel the panic of lanes closing and then the relief when you find the line.”

“People get hurt.” He wanted to say: I get hurt. He wanted to say: I always have to make sure no one else gets hurt in my stories because sometimes people in my life did. The thought made him glance at the photo on the windowsill, his father with his hand on Rafi's shoulder the day of the tiny school race he had won. His father had shouted “go” louder than the starting gun.

“If we manage it, nothing bad happens,” Leah said, as if it were both a guarantee and a prayer.

She sketched on a pad, not to scale, boxes and arrows. “We can fake ten times. Do we know where this is? The final stage.”

“Hammersmith, I think,” he said. “Or the new place they use now. Rosanna said shape different.”

“Shape different,” Leah repeated, and wrote it down like it was an instruction from a deity.

He answered his phone twice that evening, both times to producers. One was Yvonne from canteen who said, “Allergies?” and he heard her typing, the sound like rain in quality. He told her he wasn't allergic but liked to avoid anything new on performance days, like restaurants you don't know that still have warm seats from the last person. There was another man, Mike, who asked about footwear because apparently a pyrotechnics team was involved in something backstage and certain plastics were a no. He said “trainers” and the man said “brand?” and he said it and the man hummed in a way that suggested pleasing an unseen insurance company.

He packed late. He put his good things in a bag that had been to hostels and once to a strange party where he had borrowed someone's coat to feel like he belonged. He folded like a person trying to fold a future into cotton. He took oats, a small jar of ghee his mother swore by, tea bags because every tea office except theirs brewed too weak, and the tiny stove. He put in a headtorch because he was someone who put headtorches in things. He took the photo of his father and him, even though he wasn't that person, then took it out again because he didn’t want to be that person.

He went to bed and could not sleep. He lay with the ceiling close enough to touch and thought of that first time he had run. Not the first time he moved quickly as a child, which had just been a blur of knees. The first time he made it a thing with numbers and intention and a finish line. He had left the house after dinner and run to the end of the road and then to the bridge and then further because the body loves being asked to do a bit more than last time. He had returned with his lungs like bells and had told no one because he didn't know that sharing it would be safe. Over time, he had found people to share with. Leah. His mum, with her delicate questions. A coach who had told him on a Tuesday in November that he could try for a university spot if he could find a second and a half. He had not found that second and a half. He had found, instead, people on a TV show asking him to do something stranger: to make the distance inside his mind visible to a crowd.

He fell asleep in the last hour before his alarm, and when it pulled him up, he felt like he had been dragged by his ankles from a river. He made coffee strong enough to make the kitchen smell like a memory of a place with sun. He sat with Maya and they did the crossword with their usual division of labour: he did the long answers and she filled the small boxes with surprising words. She worried over his train. He told her, not unkindly, that he was a grown man. She said, not unkindly, “You have never been a grown man to me,” and he stood and gathered his bag and hugged her again at the doorway, a hug that lasted a fraction too long for comfort and exactly as long as they both needed.

On the train to London, he found a seat by the window. The river ran alongside for a while, pretending to be lazy. He thought about the city as a place with too many rooms where decisions were made. He had a notebook open on his lap, pen ready. He wrote: shape different. He wrote: a ladder that rises like a secret. He wrote: a moment where the audience thinks I'm finished and I am not. He wrote, then he crossed it out: do not fall. And then, because he had learned from experience that he had to be polite to fear, he wrote underneath it: you can fall and get back up if you need. He wrote his mother's name. He wrote the word “Brampton” as if he had to make sure it would still exist when he returned.

The studio was a warehouse that had been reborn as a cathedral of light. As he entered, he could see the weight of the ceiling and the anxiety of the walls. There were signs everywhere: STAGE THIS WAY, FOGGER ON, QUIET ZONE. There were people wearing headsets who moved as if the traffic of their ears was more important than the actual floor. He saw the paper with his name on it, taped to a door that led to a room where a kettle waited and a sofa that had seen better upholstery but still wanted to be kind. Someone had printed the paper too small. He loved them for that. He pinned it, this tiny error, as something to touch later when the minutes grew long. He put his bag down like he was checking in a memory with a cloakroom attendant.

Rosanna found him. She had hair that refused to be pinned tidy, which gave him comfort. “There you are,” she said. “Home safe?”

He didn't know if she meant the room or London or television. “Yes,” he said.

“We'll walk to stage in a moment,” she said. “Not to terrify you, but it's a beast. You'll want your footing. We've had three people slip this week and one break a heel.”

“I’m not wearing heels,” he said.

“Shame,” she said, and he liked her in that moment more than he had on the phone. “Food is down the corridor. Yvonne is a saint with a clipboard. She has your details. We’ll keep you safe.”

She said we'll keep you safe as if it meant both physical and the other kind, the kind the old producers know about, the kind where you don't get eaten by attention. He appreciated that, or maybe he just needed to hear it and so he heard it.

He met the other acts in glances and fragments. A magician whose hands shook when he wasn't performing and became stone when he was. A fourteen-year-old singer whose mother was every inch of a mother you’ve seen in television shows about mothers. A comedian who shook his hand with too much grip, registered his lack of white trousers as a personal affront, and then told him he loved his work. A dog. There is always a dog. He met a violinist who practised scales in a corner until the room tasted of resin. He tried to look like someone who belonged with them and also like someone who could leave at any moment, which is a strange posture.

Yvonne did have a clipboard. She ticked when he said his name and nodded when he said “no allergies” in a manner that implied she had heard everything. She promised him rice and chicken not complicated and warned that on show night the canteen turned into a war zone with napkins. He told her he had his own food for the day. She shrugged and said, with the cool of a ship's cook who'd seen storms swallow lesser men, “Suit yourself, love.”

Rosanna took him to the stage. The path to it was a river of cable and gaffer tape. The last corner turned and there it was: a skeleton under light. Bigger than the allotment car park. Bigger than his idea of what the body could own. The set was black and then not black where the lights tested their colours. The floor had marks like a map— Xs and arrows and circles that meant something to someone. The judges' desk was in the distance like the prow of ship. The audience's stands were empty now and still had a hungering silence, as if people had left their breath in their seats.

He stepped onto the floor slowly because this was the kind of place you didn't rush. He walked it with Rosanna, who pointed at places and said, “camera here,” and “we'll have a runner— a stage runner, not you— bring this piece on,” and “the pyro is behind that. Don't go back there unless dressed in metal.” He learned the distances. He measured in strides, then in seconds. He felt, oddly, that he could feel the ghosts of other acts in the floor. A million small scuffs. He bent and touched it with the back of his hand like a superstitious footballer, then stood quickly in case anyone had seen.

“Breathe,” Rosanna said, which he only then realised he had not been doing properly.

He thought of Leah, who would be practicing with tea on his mother's table, running her finger along the sketches. He thought of the terrier on the embankment and the old man's hand lifting and whatever home meant, exactly, when the world was this wide and askew.

“There's a media session,” Rosanna said, checking her phone for the time.

“Right.”

“Don’t say anything you'd be embarrassed to read on the front of the paper tomorrow.”

He smiled. “I don't say anything,” he said, and she laughed, then said, “Yes. That.”

He rehearsed until the lights grew less foreign. He set his boxes where they were allowed. His body learned the space like a new language. The first few runs were clumsy. He corrected. He corrected again. He surprised himself with a jump he had not planned and Leah wasn't there to tell him if it worked on camera, so he imagined her saying “there” and kept it. Midway through, he felt that light, specific ache that meant he was building something in the air. He could see the piece in his head, that imaginary line that connects beginning to end. He could feel where he wanted to break it and then heal it as the music did the same.

A boy in black trousers brought him water and said, “Big fan,” and blushed to his ears after he'd said it, and Rafi wanted to say something wise but only managed, “Thanks.” He drank like he had always been thirsty.

He checked his bag in the room again, then went to find Leah in his phone. He sent her a photo of the stage and the words: shape very different. She replied with a photo of their kitchen, with the caption: empire central. His mother had added sambal to waiting bowls. They would not let him starve. He smiled and the soundstage turned a fraction less cold. He had not then, not yet, learned the way a place can change its face when the lights are up and the people arrive and the clock is ticking toward live. He did not know yet about the canteen as a village, the corners where whispers go to reproduce, the eyes that follow, the mouths that say good luck and mean a little less than the words. He did not know yet about the lunch. He did not know yet the weight of a twist of the gut at the wrong time, or the relief of being told this is your mark by someone who believes in you, or how thin the air is at the top of something you have wanted for years.

For now, the room with his name too small on its door was still his. The boxes were still just boxes. He called his mother and listened to her tell him to tie his laces properly, even though he had long changed to a different kind of shoe that didn't tie anymore. He let her fuss. He could be large later. Here, now, in the unglamorous minute before things began, he could be the boy who had returned with wet hair and worn socks and found, on a table, a bowl of hot dal and a spoon and someone to say, Sit, tell me how far you went. He could be, fully, a person not yet seen by a million pairs of eyes. He could love the emptiness of the seats and promise them gently that he would be worth filling.

Night came earlier in that warehouse. The sky outside did what skies do. Inside, the lights took over. Yvonne's stews warmed the air in ordinary ways. Somewhere a dog barked the bark of a star. Somewhere a producer sighed in a way that meant a camera had gone wrong. Rafi laced and unlaced his shoes for no reason. He walked the corridors that looped back on themselves like thought. He passed the canteen twice and waved to the man with the tattoo of a rose that peered from his collar like a witness. He promised himself he would not eat anything he didn't trust. He promised himself he would be ferocious and gentle in equal measure. He promised himself he would remember to look up, find a face in the crowd, and then the next and the next. He promised before he had to break anything, or fix it, or be broken himself. He promised, and the building held him to it.

Chapter 2

He woke with the city already pressing its breath against the window. The hotel was the kind that wrapped you in beige in the name of calm and gave you a view of the backside of another hotel, which felt both comic and appropriate. He lay still and listened to the hum of the corridor and the odd, small noises that happen when a building full of strangers puts on its day—showers finding hot, doors kissed closed with the soft violence of the chain catch, a room-service trolley going about its pastoral duty. He missed the way Brampton had a silence that wasn't empty but was filled with things that minded their business. He pulled on his kit and went to run anyway, because the map inside him demanded it.

Outside, the city offered him a canal in lieu of a river, and men in fluorescent jackets launching their mornings on little barges of chores. He took a path that slid past graffiti that read like secret advice, past a cluster of ducks who eyed him with the long memory of creatures who know humans are erratic, past runners who nodded and gave him the fellowship of the early. He counted lampposts as always and felt, not for the first time, that the rhythm he made on pavement could be a sincere answer to a question he had never quite managed to ask out loud. On the way back he stopped on a footbridge and looked down at a bicycle submerged just under the water, its wheels catching the light indecently, and thought of all the things people throw away and all the ways they get caught, beautiful for a second in their ruin.

The studio smelt of coffee and freshly opened gaffer tape. A man in a high-vis vest with a crisp sense of purpose frog-marched a crate of cables across his line and nodded at Rafi like they were both in on a secret that involved electricity. In a conference room that had been dressed with a bowl of fruit as if that could distract from its windowlessness, the health and safety briefing gathered them in and told stories about burns and bruises with the rhythm of someone who had seen them all. A slide of a foot with a melted sole made someone gasp. Rafi took notes because taking notes was a way to carry luck in your pocket, and because the man had the farmer’s gift of turning warnings into parables. Fog machines were friendly if you knew their names. Pyro didn’t care that your mum was watching. Everything had a wake and you had to learn to live in it.

Flo, the stage manager, found him in the corridor and put a roll of tape in his hand like a priest pressing a rosary onto a sinner at the door. “Your lane,” she said, and it sounded like a benediction. She was compact and brisk and had the kind of laugh that used too few syllables and still felt like a gift. She showed him the marks that were his. She told him where the camera would be when he was meant to look at it, even though he had explained he didn’t really look at cameras, he looked at somewhere above them where his courage seemed to sit. She walked him through a plan to get his boxes on and off without creating a traffic problem. She had a list attached to her list and he loved her for that immediately.

“Media next,” Rosanna said, appearing from nowhere the way producers do when the schedule threatened to slip down the back of the sofa. “At the press lunch. You’ll be fine. Smile, breathe, say the thing you want to say and not the thing they suggest, and if somebody tries to turn your life into a one-sentence caption, step over it.”

“A press lunch?” he said. He had imagined three people in a corner with branded pop-up banners and a woman with an iPad. Lunch made it sound like there would be cutlery and opinions that wore linen.

“It’s nothing. It’s sandwiches with microphones. You’ll be grand,” she said, and he trusted her and did not trust her in equal measure because that was how these things worked.

He messaged Leah and told her when they wanted him. She replied with a photo of a hand-drawn ladder with a speech bubble that read, come on then, rise. She was getting the midday train. He felt a childish relief at the thought of her voice inside these walls. He packed his little tiffin of rice and dal into his bag even though he had now been told there would be food. He wanted to sit at a table with his own cooking like a pilgrim disobedient to a temple and watch people try not to stare at the fact that his lunch had orange on the outside and a smell like all the kitchens he trusted.

The press area was a rectangle borrowed from a different building, which meant it had the wrong carpet. Someone had thrown ferns at it to help, and a lighting rig pretended to be a skylight. Long tables were laid as if fifteen weddings were about to happen at once. Journalists had the look of people who had already written half of what they would say and were just waiting to plug in quotes like plug sockets. He took a seat between the magician and the violinist. The magician had changed his tie three times in the previous hour and now had one that looked like a piano on a good day. The violinist had put resin on her fingertips by accident and now they shone, which made her hands look like they were lit from the inside.

“Press,” the magician mouthed, and made the kind of smile you make when someone tells you an exam will be easy if you don’t think about it too hard. The first person to reach them had hair the colour of a strawberry that had won a fight and a notebook with hearts on the edges that had been drawn long ago and contaminated many interviews since. She looked at Rafi’s containers because they were not the sandwiches, then at his face, then at her list. “Rafi,” she said, steadying herself. “We loved your semi-final. You turned running into poetry. How does that feel? And, you know, being brown and everything. Representation.”

He had prepared to talk about pace and pain and the little altar you plant in your chest when you go for a time. He had not prepared to have his skin announced as if it had bought a ticket. He found his mouth choosing a sentence that would not shame either of them. “It feels like the body’s another language,” he said. “Representation is lovely, but I’m not a flag. I’m a person who moves.”

The violinist’s head tipped at that like a small bird hearing a note it liked. The journalist made a series of ticks that sounded like she was counting something other than words. “Very good,” she said. “And your mum. She’s important to you?”

He laughed because that was the safest thing to do when someone put your mum on a plate like a biscuit. “Yes,” he said. “She’s my first audience.”

There were other questions from other corners. One man asked him whether he thought Britain was ready for “alternative physical theatre,” pronouncing each word as if it had to audition for its own syllables. Someone else wondered if he had ever been bullied, and when he told the truth—only the usual kind and even then he had had friends who made jokes with him, not at him—she looked mildly disappointed. A woman with a tattoo of a swallow just inside her wrist asked him what trainers he wore and then, without any transition that made narrative sense, whether he thought footballers were overpaid. He held tight to his resolve to be kind and useful and when he was not sure he was achieving either, he pretended to be a person who had been told to talk slowly.

Midway, a man with a piece of laminated lanyard armour that had more colours than necessary introduced himself as a “brand liaison” and sat down as if he had always known Rafi. He said words like synergy with a straight face. He showed him a little sachet of neon gel as if presenting a sacrament and suggested it might be a nice moment, on camera, if Rafi “fuelled” just before he went on. Rafi thought about how his stomach did not like strangers and how he had already promised not to put anything new into his system today. He thought of the time he had eaten a pastelito in a Buenos Aires youth hostel because everyone else was eating them and spent the night talking intimately to a sink. He smiled and said, “I have my own routine. Thank you.” The man frowned as if Rafi had defied a calendar. Yvonne, watching from the serving station with arms folded and the grin of someone who enjoyed being underestimated, said, “Not today, sweetness,” in a way that placed a protective arm around him without touching him. The man moved his campaign elsewhere, and Rafi loved Yvonne more than was reasonable for someone he had known for twenty-six minutes.

He sat on the edge of the canteen’s noise and ate his food with the careful speed of a person in a buffet wars environment. The magician could not stop doing tricks, which meant his soup kept jumping without warning. The choir in coordinated blue sang happy birthday to itself, which suited Sundays but felt extravagant on a Wednesday. The comedian tried out a line about the judges and then immediately retracted it as if words could be pulled back like dogs who had gone too far off lead. The fourteen-year-old singer’s mother cut her daughter’s chicken into strict identical squares and lined them up on the plate because order always soothed someone. Rafi felt his gut tighten not with food but with the attention of people who were looking and deciding what he would be to them. He put his spoon down and breathed so his chest would get the message and stop bracing for a sprint.

Rosanna pulled him from the corner before he could think himself into knots. “Tell me it was painless,” she said, and he said, “It was a thing. I didn’t bleed,” which was as close to praise as he could get. She had a new brightness in her eye that could only mean an idea. “We’ve been talking,” she said, and the we was the sort that included people in suits and nervous laughter. “About bodies in the piece. Two movers. Not dancers, not chorus, just bodies to shift the obstacles in a way that reads more clearly for camera. You don’t have to act with them. They’ll be invisible, essentially, dressed in black. But they can make the lanes close and open so that your path is more dynamic for the wide shot. It gives us coverage. It gives you—” she searched for a word he would like and found one— “breath.”

He felt himself pull away before he could command himself to stay. The entire shape of the thing lived in his forearms and his calves and that place inside the foot where the arch holds a secret. He had built it on the faith that the obstacles were honest and only did what he told them to do. People introduced stripe and error. People tripped and apologised with their whole heads and the apology wasn’t retroactive. He heard the old thud of a memory—his father catching his elbow in a doorway when he was ten, the day they had tried to carry a table without planning it and had taken off one of the skirting boards with a laughter that had a bruise in it. He thought of Leah and the way she had sketched two humans into the plan with arrows.

“Let me try,” he said, surprising himself with the compromise. “Let me try with them and without. If it feels like a trick and not the thing, I’ll tell you.”

Rosanna nodded, relief and calculation trading glances on her face. “Of course,” she said. “Nothing is in stone until we say it is in stone.” Then she checked her phone and said, “Leah’s here. She has a rucksack that suggests she’s planning to climb a mountain.”

Leah came into the corridor like she had been summoned by the building itself. She had one of those art student rucksacks that had stains from projects and the proud slouch of something useful. She wore a coat meant for rain that had met paint more often. Her grin filled the space beside him the way light fills a jar when you take it near a window. “I am prepared to erect a city,” she said by way of greeting. “How big is your floor? How many seconds to cross it? How much fog is too much fog?”

He told her about the lunch and the suggestion and the bodies in black, and her face did a thing he recognised— worry moving over optimism like cloud over water, then breaking. “It could be good,” she said. “If they move in a way that is air, not people. If they are wind. If they are decision. And we keep you alone at the end, because it’s your piece and it must be your last image.”

“Nothing must,” he said automatically, but he knew what she meant. He knew what must felt like. He had built his mornings around it.

They rehearsed with two crew from a pool that existed primarily for this kind of question. The men were older than he expected, with knees that told their own stories, and dignity in the way they waited for instruction. They wore the black of people who had been told to be negative space. Flo gave them earpieces and quickly labelled them Mover One and Mover Two because names create softness you can’t afford on a schedule. They tried a run. The movers slid boxes on cue and opened a lane two beats later than he wanted and his foot went where a box had been as if it still existed and he had one of those heart-stopping tiny moments where you realise you have placed your body on faith. He recovered. He lied to his breath about how fast it should come. Next time they made the timing, and when they did, it felt like the floor had learned a trick he had not taught it.

He began to see how it might work. The box that would be a wall. The alley that would become a room. The ladder that might lift on the kind of stage magic that made him feel simultaneously delighted and annoyed because he did not believe things should rise unless they had earned the right with effort. Leah stood where the main camera would be and told him where he looked like a man fighting and where he looked like a man dancing, and he filed that away for the moment where he needed the latter and felt too much like the former.

On the third run he slid on a streak of something that was not supposed to be there. He caught himself with a hand to the floor and his knee jolted in a manner that made his stomach clench with the ancient memory of gym halls and iced packs and the counsel of people who begin sentences with “you’ll never.” He sat back and breathed into the joint like breath could bring calm. Flo arrived at a trot with a cloth and a look that could have stripped varnish. “I told them to keep the confetti hell off this floor,” she said, scouring. “Are you good?”

He was honest because honesty was quicker than bravado in rooms like this. “I jarred it,” he said. “It’s not broken. It’s telling me it exists.”

“Good,” she said. “We like existence. Don’t fall on live, yeah?” Her tone made it a punchline and an instruction both, and he found himself smiling because he realised he was surrounded by people whose job was to keep his hubris and his ankles from doing anything foolish.

He took a break because there was no valor in pretending the knee was not speaking. Leah sat with him on the base of a fly tower and examined the camera feed. “There,” she said, pointing to a frame where he lifted and the ladder came and it looked, briefly, as if he had conjured it. “If we time the light so it finds your foot at exactly that moment, you’ll be the pivot.”

“Flo said they can give us a white from above,” he said. “One clean white and let the rest go blue. We’ll throw shadow like a second body. It might be the thing people remember.”

Leah put her head on his shoulder the way she did when he had done something that justified her faith, and he let the shape of that compliment settle. He had the thought, quick and disloyal to all the ways he wanted not to want, that he could be the kind of person who made room for this woman in the middle of the noise. He didn’t say it. He had learned not to say things in rooms where the air had microphones even when you couldn’t see them.

The afternoon was a river he stepped into and forgot the bank. They worked. They tried a version with a beat’s silence before the ladder, and a version where the silence grew to two beats and felt pretentious, and a version where one of the movers breathed an audible “sorry” when he misheard a cue and apologised for an art no one would be able to read. He ate the banana Yvonne abandoned on a plate near his elbow like a blessing and felt nothing of the intestinal terror he had promised himself he would avoid. The stomach twist did not come with food but with a notification. It was his father, who had discovered an article online that had turned his press lunch into a wind-up toy.

Runner says show saved him, the headline read, and the photo did that thing where it froze him half-lidded and gave him the look of a man who had not slept but had been instructed to look delighted anyway. The piece quoted him out of himself. It had him saying that without this chance he “didn’t know where I’d be,” which was something humans say when they are trying to be polite about luck and get punished for it, and it made his stomach harden like a fist because he had worked in a shop and made dinners and run in the rain and he was not about to hand himself over to the idea that television had arrived like a saint with a candle. He stood there with the phone hot in his hand and felt the old anger he rarely let have the wheel and then let it go because anger burned fuel he needed for later.

“You okay?” Leah asked, because she could read a screen from the cast of a jaw. He showed her. She grunted in a register that could have knocked a wall down if it had been a little louder. “They will say what they want,” she said. “We say what we say, and the piece says what it says. Don’t feed it. Make them film the truth instead.”

He put the phone away like a thing that bit. He finished the rehearsal and found, by the time evening folded over the warehouse again, that the floor had given him a gift. The moment he had written in his notebook—where the audience would think he was done and he was not—had begun to exist. He found the beat where he stopped, the music went thin, the lights favoured the wrong place, and then he stepped where apparently there was nothing and a ladder rose as if the floor still wanted him. He let the move be smaller than the instinct demanded, and that made it better. Flo clapped once, sharp, a conductor finding the exact bar. Rosanna exhaled in a way that meant this was what they could sell. Even the technician with the rose tattoo, who had seen more than he let on, said, “Nice, mate,” like a reward to a dog for a trick that had been discouraging for months.

He wrote to his mother on the walk to the hotel because he knew she would time her worry to his footsteps. He told her he had eaten, he had not fallen, the people were kind, and he used none of the bigger sentences he wanted to use because he did not know how to put television-warmed rooms and ladders into a phone message that would arrive in a house that preferred the quiet truth of a kettle. His father called and spoke too loudly as if his voice had to fill the distance with decibels, and told him without preamble that the corner shop had stuck his face on the cigarette display because they were bored and wanted something to laugh at. His aunt from Luton sent a voice note that included six different ways of saying well done and one recipe for a lentil soup that would keep grief out of your bones. He promised nothing and everything, which is what you do when people love you.

In the hotel corridor, a thin violin found him. The violinist sat cross-legged outside her own door because maybe her roommate was sleeping and lay the instrument across her knees as if it were a small animal she was coaxing into life. He sat opposite, back against the wall like a teenager. She played scales that rose like ladders and then fell again. “Do you get scared?” he asked when the phrase ran out of breath.

“All the time,” she said, wiping the bow. “I like it. It means I’m alive.”

He thought about running as fear’s twin and smiled. He thought about a coach he had had who had once spoken of fear like it was a demon you could starve. He knew now that you didn’t starve fear. You fed it small, measured things and kept your own plate full. When he got back into his room he found a message from that very coach, forwarded and forwarded until it had lost its provenance, a link to the article with the offending headline, and the words: proud of you, keep your head, always believed. He sat with the complicated gift of that for a moment—how praise can arrive carrying the ghost of past disappointments and still be useful. He put the phone face down and let the city hands outside his window keep doing whatever they were doing without him.

At a late hour when the corridors emptied and the carpet forgot the day’s footsteps, he took the lift down to the canteen because Yvonne had promised to put aside something “with sense in it” for him. She had done it—rice, a stew that had been allowed to know what it was, a yoghurt that had not been bullied into sweetness. She sat on a stool, shoes off, and told him she had once almost fed a pop star a nut by mistake and been saved by a junior runner with an eye like a hawk. She told him tomorrow’s lunch would be busier because the Saturday magazines came to get their human interest, and advised him not to make jokes about judges, politics or the weather turning because apparently every meteorologist in the land took it personally. He thanked her and she said, with no fuss, “Just win your bit. The rest takes care of itself,” and he wished he believed that more than he did.

He slept the kind of sleep that has skirts, a handful of minutes at a time, each one wary of the next. His knee hummed and stilled, hummed and stilled. He woke before his alarm because his mind had already put on its shoes. He ran a small loop in streets that looked like themselves only after eight, then returned to the studio because there was nowhere else to go that could hold the energy he had wound up. He walked the empty seats and said hello to them in his head like a host preparing for a party, told the sixth row they would laugh, told the balcony it would get its own private performance when he looked up. He found the ladder and touched one of its rungs as a foolish lover might touch a doorpost and immediately stepped back because you don’t give inanimate objects that much control. He taped his laces down though his shoes did not need it. He put a small pebble from the Ouse on the floor beside his starting mark and Flo carefully moved it later with two fingers and a nod, which meant it was now a prop with paperwork.

The press lunch grew itself from nowhere in a sudden blooming of napkins and cameras. He felt prepared and not, which was his usual state. He chose a seat near the edge and found that his choice of edge did not matter because edges were illusions at events where everyone was invited to lean. The first question this time came from a woman who spoke softly and wrote quickly. She asked him who had taught him to run. He could have said no one and everyone and the body and hunger and the day he had not known what to do with himself at sixteen. He said his father, because it was partly true and because the words put something warm into the room. The follow-up was about his dad’s absence from Manchester. He explained a rota of work and distance and sanity and she nodded like she understood, and he felt grateful because understanding was a rare currency.

When he returned to the floor after, his stomach had that twist in it that comes when you have been seen and not entirely in the way you would have chosen, and he did the only thing he knew to do with that feeling. He ran the piece. He ran it twice and then again. He ran it like a man reminding himself what belongs to him regardless of who is looking. He found the breath inside it that Rosanna had promised and the wind that Leah had asked for and the quiet moment that would mean everything in a room designed to overtalk. He jumped and did not fall. He looked up the way he had promised and found faces that were not there yet and rehearsed the nod he would give to them. He shaped the movement so that even people who thought they hated running might love watching him try to turn leaving and returning into something they could feel in their own legs.

He did not know what the cameras would decide he meant. He did not know what the show would edit him into. He knew what his body was for. He knew what the floor could hold. He knew the exact number of steps from the mark to the place where the ladder would lift and he would look, for a heartbeat, like a person who had summoned something from nowhere and it had obeyed. He let that be enough until the door of the day opened again and everything he had promised himself to be began to be tested.

Chapter 4

He came home with London still stuck to his skin like a second weather. The train had delivered him into the geography that made sense, the one with hedges that had arguments with themselves and a sky that kept staring as if it had known him since he was small. The village was doing what villages do on a Monday after someone from there has been on the telly: pretending it hadn’t noticed and then noticing in a surge at the butcher’s, or outside the post office, or in the way a window’s curtain twitched like a blink. He stood in his own hallway with its damp wool smell, put his bag down exactly where it always bruised the skirting board, and breathed as if breath was a thing you had to practise after days of being watched.

He ran before he had a chance to think better of it. The cold had sharpened while he was away, the air brushing his teeth from the inside. The Ouse had its shoulders up as if it too had felt, in some reptile part of its current, the weight of lights miles away. He found the path as if it had been sleeping with one eye open for him and now wanted a report. His knee told him, oh yes, hello, we remember, and then settled under the familiar bargain of warmth. The old man with the terrier appeared where he always appeared, conjured by habit and the smell of wet earth. They did not nod this time. The man lifted his chin and spoke the way you speak when you’ve been rehearsing lines for weeks. “Saw you,” he said. “Saw you jump. Good, that.”

Rafi wanted to say that he had not so much jumped as negotiated with gravity and paperwork. He said, “Thank you,” and the terrier, whose eyes had known sorrow and left a little room for joy despite it, gave a bark that sounded like agreement. “Name’s Jim,” the man added, which felt like a medal more than a name. “Dog’s Mavis. Don’t laugh.” Rafi didn’t. He ran on with Mavis’s bark making a neat knot at the end of his last sentence.

On the way back he let his stride lengthen as if he were opening a book too quickly and then forced it smaller because speed had nowhere to be today. He stopped where the once-started hedge still made a promise to the future and couldn’t quite keep it. He touched the scar on his gums with his tongue out of habit. He considered the map of his village anew. There would have to be a new mark now: here, the place where he had thought, after the final, sitting on a dressing-room sofa with glitter sticking to his forearms like a broken galaxy, that relief felt like a betrayal. He had not won. He knew that saying it like that made it sound heavy and it was not quite heavy, it was a stone he could put in his pocket and forget until he reached in for keys. The dog had won, in the end, which was a sentence you can say about many British evenings. The choir had sung as if the roof would be kind. The magician had turned his hands into a church and still lost, which he had expected and not expected. The fourteen-year-old had been brilliant in the way fourteen-year-olds are brilliant—pure and unarmoured and completely unprepared for what morning papers can do. He had stood under falling confetti cut in the shapes of stars that did not look like any stars he trusted, and smiled until his face asked to clock off.

If you had asked him for an image of his own performance, he would have given you the moment he had expected to go to sleep over and over in the night and never did: the quiet, the lights looking the wrong way on purpose, the breath coming like a well-behaved animal, and then that small step into somewhere that decided to be there exactly when he needed it. The ladder rose. The room made a sound it did on its own, a collective intake that turned ribs into instruments. He had not fallen. The knee had held. Mover One and Mover Two had moved like the idea of air. Flo had been a metronome with a voice. Rosanna had squeezed his shoulder and said “yes” not about television, but about the fact that someone had asked for a difficult thing and he had brought it. Amanda had found her word again and called it modern. Simon had tried to pretend he was immune to surprise and had failed in the half-second you cannot control. The cameras had caught one angle he had not wanted them to and three that he knew would make strangers think of their own breath. He found in the minutes after that he could stand being congratulated if he arranged the compliments in a line like shoes at a door and did not pick any of them up.

“Tea,” Maya said, already halfway to the kettle because she believed more devoutly than any saint in the doctrine of hot water. She had watched from the sofa with a cushion on her lap as if it could have protected him if the ladder had misbehaved. Her eyes were red in a way he recognised from colds and from weddings. She pressed her hand to his cheek now and then, as if the television had been a cold room and she needed to make sure he’d warmed through again. “Your father,” she added, and did not have to finish because he could guess the list that followed. The calls. The texts. The fact that Rafi’s uncle had filmed his own television with his phone and posted the recording to a WhatsApp group with a pride that had smeared every technical detail until sound and image were cousins but not siblings.

His father arrived before the cups had finished steaming, as if the distance from where he lived to their door was elastic and television had stretched it. He came in with the air of a man who had delivered a small baby and needed someone to sign for it. “You,” he said, and then did something Rafi had not seen him do except once when Pakistan had won a cricket match on the last ball—he sat down abruptly and was quiet. The quiet did more than the words. After a time the words caught up. “My boy,” he said. “You made them listen without talking.”

“It’s all talking,” Rafi said, because he had learned that moving was reading aloud with different punctuation. His father brushed a crumb from the table like a man mending a roof. “They will call,” he said. “All the agents. You tell me. We will choose.”

Rafi looked at his mother over the lip of his cup and found in her eyes the thought he was having to swallow. Choose what. Choose between what and what. There were emails already, of course. One from a sportswear brand that used the word icon as if it could be stuck to a person like a sticker. One from a casting director who had the kind of signature that included Latin for no good reason and suggested a role in an advert where he would need to look at a camera like a man who both loved and respected a chocolate bar. One from a school in Peterborough asking if he could come and “inspire” the Year Tens, which he wanted to do more than he wanted to do almost anything because Year Tens needed all the gentle hands you could find. He had the feeling of standing in a meadow at dusk where gnats rise in columns and you do not know which one will end up in your eye.

Vince rang from the shop and left a message that began, “Are you alive,” and continued, “Please come in and be normal; people keep trying to buy spaghetti like they know you now.” Leah texted a photo of the village hall with the caption: imagine. He did. He could see the chalk lines on polished wood. He could see plastic chairs stacked like possibilities along the wall. He could see their ladder against the stage and the way the local light would love it more than any studio could. “We can build it here,” he said aloud without meaning to. His mother, who had more talent than anyone he knew for hearing things you hadn’t meant to say, nodded like a woman whose faith had been waiting for an altar. “We can,” she said. “We have tables.”

They went shopping because life insists on it. The co-op had arranged itself around him like a stage does around its lead without admitting to it. He tried to move as if he were not something people had opinions about. Vince tried to play it cool and failed by half. He made a little show of not ringing up the honey properly and then looked panicked until Rafi laughed and rescued him with the barcode. “How was it?” Vince asked, and Rafi considered giving him a paragraph and gave him nine words instead. “Big room. Good people. I didn’t fall. It was loud.” Vince nodded as if these were all the data points one needed to survive fame. A woman he had never seen before touched his sleeve in the drinks aisle and said, “Our boy,” as if she had birthed him in the queue at the post office. He bought more oats than anyone needed and a jar of mango pickle because the labels made him feel like the shelf would keep holding.

At home, Leah came with her rucksack stuffed to the drawstring lip, and the wind in her hair said she had cycled and almost run. She had watched the final with her landlady and two houseplants and had cried at what he knew she would cry at, which was not the ladder but the small moment he had salted the air with his hands in remembrance of the bits he couldn’t bring with him. She held his face for a beat longer than friends sometimes do and then they got down to the business of making. “We can do Tuesdays and Thursdays at the hall,” she said, pulling a notebook that looked like a patient from the bag. “There’s a Tuesday upholstery group but they finish at eight and we can talk them into giving us the last half hour of their session if we can promise not to tread on the foam. Mr. Singh at the hardware will let me borrow two trestles if we bring them back clean. I asked about the ladder. There is one. It is questionable. But we can reinforce. I know a man with screws.”

He answered emails with the care of a person unscrewing a jammed jar. He wrote to the school and said yes. He wrote to the brand and said thank you, no, unless they wanted to help them tour a piece to small towns and keep ticket prices low, in which case yes, absolutely, talk to him about how. He wrote to the casting director and said there was a voice in him that told him to love chocolate but it was not a face he wanted to show. He wrote to a woman called Saira who had somehow found his email and who ran a community centre in Kettering and said, could you come talk to our lads who never sit still, and he wrote yes so quickly that his fingers caught on the keys. He wrote to Rosanna and told her plainly that the show had not saved him, but the room had been kind and that he would be grateful to the floor for as long as he could remember floors. Rosanna wrote back with a sentence he would keep for a while: The room is a room because people like you come into it.

He went back to the track two days later because he wanted to see if the old ghosts would still hum. The coach who had told him, once upon a year heavy with numbers, that he would need a second and a half, was there in his cap with the salt stain. The man looked at him and did the British thing with his mouth where he prepared for emotion and then strapped it down and let it out anyway. “I was wrong about you,” he said, and Rafi held up a hand because wrongness about the past was not the flavour of the day he could digest. “No,” he said. “You were right about that second. I never found it. I found other seconds. They still count.” They ran a little, not because anyone needed to but because the simple act of stepping in rhythm with another person slapped meaning onto the air. The coach, whose name was Lawrence but whom everyone called Lo because the long name didn’t suit him unless you were telling him off, watched his knee the way a doctor watches a test result. “Careful,” he said, not dour, not doom, just an offering. “You’re about to be pulled at by people who don’t know your body. Keep some for yourself.”

He and Leah took their shoes off at the door of the village hall because the caretaker had that rule and also because respect is a thing you can practise. The place was a museum of minor triumphs. A faded noticeboard announced a jumble sale from 2007 with a zeal that time had not dimmed. The stage had curtains that had retired from being loudly red but still liked to remember the job. They chalked the floor and the chalk made their own stars, small and honest. Kids from the after-school club peered in and they let them, because the best way to start a myth is to let someone watch without paying for it. Leah moved the boxes like a librarian moving books. They practised the ladder’s rise with a carefulness that felt like prayer and a rope that could have been a snake if it had tried harder. At eight forty-five Mr. Potter from the upholstery group popped his head back in and said, would they be needing the foam offcuts, and Leah said, keep your offcuts, we love you, and Mr. Potter blushed because no one had said that to him in decades and he’d thought he was long done with blushing.

Money came into conversations like weather. They drew up a list of expenses and it made a thin column and then grew fatter when they remembered things like insurance and leaflets and the fact that people liked soft lighting even when they said they didn’t. They applied for funds with a form that asked them to perform humility and ambition on the same page. Leah had more patience for boxes than he did and he blessed her with snacks and praise while she translated their bodies into words for a panel somewhere that would read them while eating a sandwich and deciding futures between bites. His father called with a business plan that relied heavily on the idea that people would pay to watch him run like a man on fire. His mother suggested the most sensible thing of all: ask the village to borrow space and time and hands. “You all raise each other here,” she said. “That is why we live in a place like this.”

They did a small thing first. A showing, Leah called it, though the piece was not a show yet, it was a creature being coaxed. They put three rows of chairs at the front and made tea and brought biscuits that were not posh but were offered like jewels. Thirty people came, which felt like a crowd made of relatives and the curious. His aunt drove from Luton and sat ramrod straight as if posture could keep the world’s nonsense out. Jim came with Mavis and apologised when she barked with excitement exactly at the moment Rafi hopped the pretend fence, and then everyone laughed and the laugh was the kind that makes you feel you are exactly where you should be. He ran the piece small. No fog. No pyro. No camera that could see better than human eyes. He let the silence grow where it had grown under lights and found it did something different in a room with a notice about Tai Chi peeling at the corners. At the end, he stood and there was a second where he wanted to say something. He didn’t. He bowed like someone whose mother had taught him what to do with gratitude in public, and Leah’s eyes said: it works even when it whispers.

The day after, messages came of the kind that matter. “My lad is ten and never sits,” Saira wrote back to say, “he sat.” A man who had not spoken at the showing sent a photograph of his trainers at the door and wrote, “Ran this morning for the first time in twenty years. My knees are cross. Feels good.” The school in Peterborough gave him a date and asked if they could film if they promised to delete every frame with a child’s face, which was the kind of promise you signed your name to even though you knew the digital world could still smuggle you. He and Leah made a poster and took it to the post office and the woman behind the counter made a display that somehow made the word mile look like a cousin of miracle without anyone choosing that on purpose.

One afternoon, when the rain found its confidence again and did what it did to the lanes with relish, an email came from a man who formatted his name with a lot of capital letters and asked whether Rafi would consider joining a “celebrity series” where he would be paired with a gymnast and teach them to “tell their story through the medium of sprint.” Rafi read it and thought of dollars and the sound of his mother’s shoes on the stair and the pinboard on the fridge. He closed his eyes and saw two numbers: the cost of a new boiler and the cost of saying no. He wrote back that he was flattered, he was even grateful, but he was building a thing that did not survive well in rooms where story wore sequins and judges. The man wrote back a line that had the taste of a threat and he kept the email as proof that sometimes the world did not deserve the care you took with your sentences.

The distribution centre wrote too, finally, with the tone of an invitation that had lost its sprightliness. They were “currently fully staffed” but would “keep his details on file.” He stared at that and had the odd sensation of falling without moving. Relief and resentment found the same chair. He picked the kettle up, put it down, picked it up again. He would need money. The piece would need money. He could clean the hall on Saturdays. He could stack cereals with a religiousness that still amused Vince. He could say yes to the school talks and the community centres and take the fees and make a stained-glass window out of small notes and coins and warm soup. He could ask his father to lay aside the bit of him that liked a miracle in exchange for the bit that was good with a hammer and shelves. He could live in the space between enough and not enough and build something steady.

On a morning that was almost spring if you squinted, Lo came to the hall and watched from the back like a man assessing a field for yield. He did not take notes because there are some things you don’t make lists about. When Rafi had finished a section, he said, “You’re doing the thing I tell the kids when they ask me about sprint and I say, it’s about leaving without forgetting to take yourself. You go and you stay at the same time. It makes people cry. They don’t know why.” Rafi laughed because the line was too neat and not, and then his eyes did the thing you don’t make jokes about. He put his hands on his thighs and breathed and said, “Tea,” because there were words he could not say in daylight to men who had taught him other words.

They got a small grant that paid for light and for Leah’s time in a way that made her sit down at the kitchen table and momentarily forget how to swallow. They got a call from a theatre in Cambridge that had a black box they weren’t using on three consecutive Tuesdays and would they like to come and make the floor scuff on purpose. They said yes to all of it and then took turns remembering to sleep. Flo texted him a photo of a roll of tape with the words: it’s still ours if you need it. Yvonne sent a message without warning: stew recipe, foolproof, will feed the whole hall, please stop starving out there, x. Rosanna appeared in his inbox sometimes with a link to an article about how attention becomes a job. He read them all. He did not fall through the cracks in between because Brampton was a net.

There were new small rituals. He put the pebble from the soundstage by the back door and touched it before he left as if he were proving to it that he was not being unfaithful to the floor he had loved before. He fixed the stuck front door instead of shouldering it because you can only slam against resistance for so long before it makes a pattern in you. He did the crossword with his mother even when he was late because clues are a way to believe in answers and they had both earned that belief. He took Mavis a pig ear he had looked up to make sure did not ruin dog stomachs, and Jim accepted it with the solemnity of a man who had buried three people and knew the value of small comforts. “You didn’t fall,” Jim said again one morning apropos of nothing, and Rafi said, “Not then,” and Jim nodded like a man who had watched a lifetime of then and now and knew both could change their minds.

The day they loaded the ladder into the back of a borrowed van to drive it to Cambridge, his phone rang with a number he didn’t know. He balanced the rung against his shoulder and answered because he had started to practise saying hello to the unknown. The voice on the other end was warm and had the kind of smile that makes sound. She said her name was Kaia and that she worked with a festival of “small and intense things” in the north. She had seen a clip in an ecosystem she refused to name and wanted to know if he would like to bring his mile to a room in a library that had a ceiling that understood hush and a floor that was tired of chairs. “We have no money,” she said, “but we have bread and a roomful of people with ears.” He looked at Leah who looked at him with the greed of a woman who loves bread and ears more than most things money can buy. He said yes and felt the click it made in the map of the year. He did not yet know the road or the hotel with beige and no windows, or the one person in that northern library who would stand up too quickly when he finished and knock his knee on the chair and swear softly and then go outside and run because sometimes you have to obey your legs immediately. He did not know that his father would learn how to livestream a Northern festival and that his mother would think every town with rain was the same and worry accordingly. He did not know that he would learn to sleep on trains better than in beds and that he would acquire the precise understanding of which Tupperware lids never betray you. He did not know that people would begin to email him with their runs—their first, their worst, their mornings—and that his inbox would become, in its way, a cardiology ward.

He knew only that he would keep moving until the map of where he had been began to look like a story. He knew the line between attention and being seen and he put his foot on the one he wanted. He knew that he would eat the stew Yvonne had vouchsafed with a confidence that would make his mother both proud and slightly jealous. He knew that he loved Leah in a way that hovered companionably near words but did not force them, and that if anyone tried to force them for him he would run the other way for a bit and then circle back and tell her anyway in a yard between a hall and a hedge. He knew that when the sky made up its mind and cracked into blue, there would be speed and he would offer it to the nearest patch of air like a gift that cost both of them something and returned more than it took. He knew, with a surety that made the floor less wobbly, that he would still be here in the mornings, when the mist rolled off the Ouse like steam from an overworked kettle, and that the path would greet him as if he hadn’t left at all.

Chapter 6

The van had been borrowed from a man who trusted everyone until about 1998 and had been practising caution ever since. It smelt of old rugs and something like cloves, and the glove compartment contained a map of Britain that showed motorways as if they were bravely invented yesterday. Rafi and Leah wedged the ladder with a lattice of bungee cords and promises, and tucked boxes around it the way you tuck blankets around a sleeping child. Maya stood at the gate holding a flask like a benediction. She had wrapped sandwiches in greaseproof paper because she refused to believe in cellophane. “Bread and ears,” she said, because she had liked that line and had turned it into a packing instruction. Rafi kissed her cheek twice, once for the road and once for the return, and his father pretended he was indifferent to the van’s rust while checking its tyres with the toe of his shoe in a way that suggested prayer.

They drove north with the ladder humming like a tuning fork every time they crossed a seam in the road. The hedges broke up into moors that looked like a map had been rubbed until it forgot the edges of things. Leah read out place names like charms. She kept a list she said she would use for characters she had not met yet: Kirkby Stephen, Barnard Castle, Stainmore. She sang, quietly, because she sang to the road the way some people sang to kettles to make them boil faster. They stopped once on the hard shoulder because the rear door made a sound that had to be investigated immediately and found nothing but wind, which was reassuring and not. They ate the sandwiches in a lay-by where a lunching lorry driver offered them leftover apples with the generosity of someone who liked to see people moving a purpose in a van not meant for glamour. When the land began to dissolve into brick and viaduct and a river surprisingly wide, Leah reached over and put her hand on Rafi’s knee like a reminder that bodies have anchors, and he felt the ladder’s humming stop inside him even as the van rattled on.

Kaia met them on the library steps with a scarf that could have padded a house. She had hair that did not obey a straight line and a way of looking at you as if she were borrowing your face for a painting. The library itself had the air of a cathedral that had run out of saints and started stocking paperbacks instead. Stone rubbed by years fell down into carpet gone bald in particular patches; the ceiling had the kind of arches that make you instinctively whisper. “You found us,” Kaia said, as if other people had set off for this place and never arrived. “Excellent. I’ve got three volunteers and a librarian called Mr. Dalton who uses silence like a weapon, but he’s agreed to let us have a bit of noise if it’s useful noise.” She led them in past posters for poetry nights and a notice about a knitting group that had chosen a name with a pun in it and then regretted it. Children were being taught to handle books like animals. An old man slept with his mouth open under a banner that read READ YOUR WAY TO FAR PLACES, which felt like a lesson in how to take instructions seriously.

They set the space the way you arrange a table for people you care about. Between stacks and a stairwell they conjured a lane. Leah held a tape measure with the look of a person holding a wand, and Rafi learned the dimensions of aisles with a respect usually reserved for rivers. They met the volunteers: a boy with a hoodie bitten by cigarette burns who laughed like he was apologising for something from three summers ago; a woman who had brought her daughter and told Kaia plain that she’d come to see if someone could make her teenager listen without shouting; a retired teacher called Moira who had the kind of competence that makes you check your shoelaces for neatness. Mr. Dalton appeared like a plot point and approved the positioning of a rubber mat with the solemnity of an altar boy. “No running between the stacks,” he said automatically, and then stopped himself, and something like a laugh cracked the dryness around his mouth.

In rehearsal, the ladders seemed almost pious in that room. The hum of circulation was different, the air full of the damp wool of coats and library breath. The floor gave a hush back to his shoe that made him weigh every footfall as if each could be a word too loud. He found out fast that the turn by the returns desk needed to be slower or the corner of an oak shelf was going to acquaint itself with his ribs in a way they would all regret. Leah adjusted the timing of light because there was no light to adjust; she placed lamps instead, desk lamps with green glass shades borrowed from the room upstairs, and called it design like a dare. The volunteers offered their hands, and in the absence of headsets and Flo’s choreography, they moved the boxes with a gentleness that made Rafi’s throat tighten because they were moving more than objects. The hoodie boy watched the line he was making with suspicion and then pride, which is how roads get built. When they ran the piece the first time, someone in the upstairs reading room dropped a book and the thud rolled down the stairwell like a thought that had reconsidered. Kaia stood at the back with her arms folded, not in judgement but like a person trying to contain heat between her ribs and spare it for later.

The audience came like weather. They weren’t fans, not like in a television studio; they were an arrangement of neighbors, city strangers, stray lunchers, and three women whose hair was perfect in a manner that meant time had been spent. A man in a suit sat alone and took off his watch as if to agree to being here. A little girl chewed the end of her sleeve and then stopped because her mother squeezed her hand once and that was all the instruction necessary. A student with a ring in his lip studiously pretended to be bored and then failed. When Rafi began, it wasn’t with the drum of a TV track; it was with the sound of a pencil somewhere, with the crackle of a radiator trying to be useful, with the slow intake of breath that libraries require before anything happens. He laid out his distance between the stacks like you lay out an argument between people who love each other. He kept some of the big beats, because they were honest, but the room took the volume it could bear and returned it as resonance rather than thunder.

The ladder’s rise in that building was stranger and cleaner than it had ever been. A corner light hit the rung as if it had been waiting its whole career for this job. Someone made a noise that would have got you shushed in another context and Mr. Dalton did not shush them. Rafi found the pause he had marked in pencil in his head and let it deepen because the room held him up instead of gravity. When he finished he didn’t bow so much as tilt, because there was no stage for the gesture to land on. The suit man stood too quickly and banged his knee on the chair in front; he swore, and then laughed, and then left, and then, through the glass doors, Rafi saw him run a short way down the street like someone who had remembered an appointment with his old self. A woman cried in the way you cry when you remember to blink. Kaia clapped alone at first, and then together was made, and it was enough.

After, they ate the bread. Kaia had meant it literally. There were loaves from the bakery around the corner, a loaf with seeds that dared you to bite and one with a gloss as if it had been varnished. There were bowls of soup that had been called “with substance” on the poster, and for once the truth matched the taste. People queued as they do when English people are determined to be orderly even about gratitude. The hoodie boy took two bowls and a crust and left without speaking to anyone except Leah, to whom he said, “That bit where you do the small jump and then the little one—I thought you were going to not,” which was how you made hospitality into a review. Moira squeezed Rafi’s forearm with a pressure that would cut diamonds. Mr. Dalton said, “Books can’t do everything,” and his voice had to fight its own dryness to get out. Kaia introduced them to a poet who was writing a book about attention, and he laughed at the idea as if it were a cat that had sat on the piano instead of Bach.

They slept above a bakery that night in a bed that had seen things but was still doing its job with dignity. The room held a tiny sink that could not commit to being hot but was charming about it. The scent of tomorrow’s bread rose through the floorboards and made everything seem kinder. Leah sat at the end of the bed with her legs tucked under and drew the shelves out of memory in a notebook that had lost the first ten pages years ago and did not miss them. Rafi lay down and then sat up and then lay down again because his knee had begun to hum with the smugness of effort. They talked with their heads against the wall because walls listen differently. Leah said she had been invited to a residency in Glasgow by a woman who made art with light and patience and a toaster she treated like a pet, and the residency came with access to equipment and a stipend so small it would pay for exactly the amount of coffee she couldn’t drink or she would jitter through ceilings. She asked what he thought like you ask a mirror for advice.
