He looked at her and saw the thread of her work unspooling on another city’s pavement; he saw nights without her voice settling the corners of a room with jokes thin as knives; he felt a little jealous and told the truth anyone who loves a person who makes things has to learn. “Go,” he said, and then added, because he could not help it and did not want to, “and come back or let me come to you; there’s no prize for choosing one world forever.”

They got up at a time that was not morning or night and went out to find the bakery already in full hymn. The woman behind the till identified them as the ladder people and smuggled a bun into their bag and told them not to argue. They drove home with the ladder less talkative, as if it had learned something it needed to chew on. The hills leaned nearer to the van on the way back, or perhaps it was only that Rafi and Leah had become quieter and so the landscape took the opportunity to speak. They stopped once to pee in a lay-by and Leah used a toilet in a caff that had a notice reading NO POETS above the hand dryer; she came back with a grin that stayed for three junctions. They made a game of counting the number of times Rafi’s father would pretend he had only just arrived when they pulled into the street and he was already standing at the gate with a screwdriver and news.

Bringing the piece home from elsewhere changed its shape. The village hall looked at them like a friend who has read the book you love and has questions. People began to treat Tuesday and Thursday as events you could add to a calendar. There were teenagers at the back pretending not to look and older men pretending they were just walking by and then discovering their feet chose the door. Saira sent a message saying the Kettering lads had given a standing ovation that had been twenty percent mockery and eighty percent sincere, and so, balanced, had not collapsed. The school in Peterborough had set a date and, in a line that should have only belonged to farce, asked if they could bring the ladder, and Rafi wrote back that they would bring two ladders if it would make the boys think twice about what you can build.

At Peterborough he watched a boy throw his jacket at a chair like a gauntlet and then sit on the floor when everyone else sat on chairs because chairs are an allegiance. He watched a girl who had drawn eyes on her hands so she could look twice. He began the way he had learned to begin with young people: without a preamble, as if you had burst into their day and would leave it and they should be allowed to decide whether you were a thief or a guest. He did a small version and let the pauses be longer than the impatient part of him preferred, and the room rewarded him with a silence that had purpose. When they asked questions, the boy with the chair jacket asked, “What do you do if you can’t run,” and the question did not care about shin splints. Rafi looked at his knee and then at his hands and then at the bit of the floor where the polish had given up. “You find the bit of your body that still moves,” he said. “It might be a very small bit. You do that bit until the rest remembers. Or you borrow someone else’s bit. People can be very useful.” The boy absorbed that, or pretended to, and then held the edge of a box while Rafi shifted it, and their hands bumped in a way that told Rafi as much about adolescence as any book would have.

His father, consistent as tide, tried to find the agent before the agent found him. Two men called about being intermediaries between him and brands, and one woman offered him “a friendly shape to your decisions,” which sounded like the softest threat. His father liked the woman because she had a voice that reminded him of a radio show from 1994, and he disliked the men because one of them wore a scarf indoors. They sat in the kitchen with the kettle ticking like a metronome and argued in the respectful register they had learned when Rafi was sixteen and almost catastrophic. “You have to say yes to one of them,” his father said. “The world doesn’t just let people make things. It takes tax, it takes time, it takes money, and if someone wants to pay for your shoes, let them pay.” Rafi, carefully, because he had been careless before and it always cost, tried to explain that the wrong money pulled the wrong thread and then you found your jumper in your hands. “We can do it small,” he said. “We can do it slow. We can do it with people and bread and roofs that leak and a poster in the post office. I don’t want to be a thing you can buy in the bits between talent shows.” His father drank tea as if it were a counterargument. The words made marks on the table that wiped away later because love typically has a cloth ready. They compromised, because both of them were good at it: his father would keep collecting messages in a notebook with a phone number Maya had insisted not be Rafi’s, and Rafi would promise to listen to one pitch a week so that they would not miss the good fish while swearing off trawlers.

He hurt his knee properly in March, which was silly because it happened when he stumbled on the two inches between the hall’s stage and the floor, a danger everyone knew and therefore no one saw. He felt the familiar pull and something like tearing paper, and he swore quietly and sat and then lay down because sitting wasn’t enough and lying down was too much, and Leah’s face above him did that thing faces do when they want to be two faces at once: a calm one for the person looking up and a panicked one for the room. Lo arrived because someone had texted him and he always arrived when knees were involved. He poked and said kind things that had verbs in them and made telephone calls to a physiotherapist who had a waiting list and a soft spot for teachers, and managed to make Rafi feel that this was a perimeter rather than a cliff. For a week he didn’t run. He learned the weight of walking again as if it were a skill. He taped up with a seriousness that would have made Flo proud and slept with his leg arranged like a question he was trying to answer politely.

The piece learned to live without speed. Leah, who understood that form is what you do when the old shape won’t hold, took the boxes and made a different language with them. She placed them so that moving through them was like reading a poem out loud when there’s a word you have to pause for because it belongs to a dead friend. Rafi found a way to show breath without taking off. He learned to let stillness be the trick instead of the trick being proof he could conquer the floor. In the hall, the teenagers at the back unlocked their shoulders because stillness felt less like being dared and more like being let in; at the library in the second town Kaia sent them to, a woman who had once danced in nightclubs and now danced in her kitchen stood and showed him how hips remember even when knees don’t, and he gave her back the microphone he did not have.

Kaia kept calling. Her festival of small and intense things had found itself a circuit by accident. Libraries told other libraries that a boy came and made their carpet do something worthwhile. Community centres added “breath and ladders” to their schedules in between Pilates and toddler sessions. A town with a pier written in a language the water understood asked them to bring the piece at dusk, and they learned that gulls have an opinion about everything. They stayed above pubs and in spare rooms and once in a house where the owners were away and had left a note that said, help yourself to anything except the rhubarb gin, and then added in a different handwriting, especially the rhubarb gin. On a bus somewhere between Derby and Mansfield a girl watched Rafi online and then realised it was him and did that narrow-eyed calculation people do when they are trying to decide whether a human and their image can be reconciled, and then said, “You looked taller,” and he mended her disappointment with a joke about ladders. Leah’s email came, with the Glasgow residency’s proper words and stamp and a promise of a tiny stipend and a larger room, and she sat with it as if someone had offered her a life she couldn’t remember ordering. They promised each other something without fingernails for grip and chose to call it a plan.

Television called too. A producer whose voice had been cleverer than him when he was tired left a message about “Champions,” a specials programme made mostly of people whose names had put on muscle, and suggested a return that would be “good for your brand presence.” The email that followed was full of everything that had made him stand up straighter and run the other way since the final: time slots, the name of a singer whose management would be “delighted to cross-promote,” a suggestion that they could “enhance” the piece with aerial silk because audiences loved vertical. He read it twice and then stood in the kitchen and told the kettle everything he wanted to say because kettles are good at confidentiality. He wrote back in careful we’s instead of I’s, because he had learned to be plural for the work that mattered. He thanked them and did not say yes; he thanked them and did not say no; he asked them what they could do for a tour of libraries and village halls and youth clubs with no pyro at all. Then he put his phone on the dresser and went to the hall to show Leah how stillness could be more arrogant than a leap.

The day the Glasgow decision became a yes, they took the news to the river. The Ouse had its shoulders down. Swans moved like they were trying not to be blamed for anything. Leah carried a paper bag with two doughnuts you had to eat immediately or regret for hours. They sat on the low wall and the stone showed them last summer in flaws and fossil and foot. Leah was effervescent in the way she got when it wasn’t about speech, her hands making patterns in the air that made Rafi want to map the air itself. He tried to say he would be fine and instead said, “I want the sound of you to stay in the room,” and she put her head on his shoulder and said, “Then you’ll have to make rooms that hold sound,” and it was the sort of exchange that looks like nothing from the outside and becomes, later, a hinge.

They celebrated in a fashion that no one would have recognised as such. They ate dal with the last of the ghee Maya had tucked at the back of the cupboard for a winter emergency and called this as close as they could get. They invited Lo and Kaia because Kaia had arrived in time for a showing and was sleeping on the sofa with a blanket that smelt faintly of bonfires. Yvonne sent a parcel that looked like a practical joke and turned out to be spices and recipes and a note that read, “If you can’t eat well, you can’t do anything well, stop arguing with me.” Rosanna wrote an email that was longer than a text and shorter than a letter, congratulating and advising and not asking for anything back. Rafi’s father opened a bottle from the bottom of a cupboard and the cork became a small missile that dots the paintwork still.

There were setbacks that did not deserve capital letters and earned them anyway in the diaries of people invested. A volunteer in Hull dropped a box on her toe and went home swearing that the show had made her foot religious. The van lost its right brake light because a boy on a bike had invented a theory that it would survive a smack and was wrong. A form for a small grant disappeared into an email address that was technically alive and practically dead, and Leah called it the bureaucracy of ghosts. A man in a town whose name began with C took exception to the fact that Rafi had said no to returning to television and wrote him a letter in capitals explaining exactly why he was letting the village down; the letter went up on the kitchen pinboard and down again when Maya decided the wall deserved better manners. There were mornings when the damp got into the hall and into Rafi’s bone, and he did the thing he had taught other people to do: he moved the very small bit that still moved.

The day before Leah left for Glasgow, they drove to the coast because the map needed an edge. The sea was grey and honest. They took their shoes off and let their ankles forget they belonged to land; they ran, slowly for Rafi and normally for Leah, and the sand kept their secrets. They used the wind like a friend you can shout into and not annoy. On the way back they stopped in a café heavily invested in bunting and shared a plate of chips with the seriousness of people agreeing terms. They talked about schedules until schedules began to sound like a game of snakes and ladders. They sat in the car on the lane into Brampton with the radio on low and neither of them could remember what the presenter had been saying, which was perfect because it meant the words between them had been louder. At the door, Maya hugged Leah like a daughter and muttered instructions about keeping warm near radiators and not trusting men who smiled with just their mouths. Rafi watched Leah pull her bag up her shoulder and knew in the plainest possible way what people mean when they say something will take time.

It did. The weeks that followed had an odd gait. The house was the same size and had to redistribute its echoes. Rafi ran early and late. He attempted a crossword and his mother filled in two clues for him because she mistrusted long words more than she mistrusted bad weather. He stood in the hall alone and broke chalk with his thumb and remembered to warm up because forgetting now had consequences. He put the ladder up and the ladder looked taller without Leah’s hands on it, and he stood at the bottom of it and had the sensible thought that he should not go up, and then the less sensible thought that he could teach other hands to place it well. He invited the Brampton football lads to a session with the inducement of hot chocolate, and they arrived with their scepticism like an extra layer and left with their cheeks raw and their layers on their arms.

Leah sent photos of equipment that looked like astrology. She sent a message about a light that was both a square and not a square, which thrilled her half to distraction. She sent a picture of a street she had walked at three in the morning because her head had not read Glasgow’s bedtimes properly yet and she had gone out to argue. She sent a video of a toaster that had become a sculpture and then, because Leah could not resist, toast. Rafi sent her a small clip of a boy in the hall skipping the way kids skip without remembering when they learned, and a woman in a cardigan too big for her shoulder width who cried when he paused, and a stack of chairs because she liked chairs even when she said she didn’t. They kept each other always by at least two streets and a coil of wire, and when they did not speak, they did not panic. Sometimes he caught himself counting his breaths in her voice and did not tell her because he wanted the trick to last.

The library in the third town had a leak and warning tape that made everything look like a crime scene. They did it anyway because water and art have always had to learn to tolerate each other. Mr. Dalton had told his cousin, it turned out, and the cousin was the librarian here, and he had entirely different ideas about noise and had printed out signs that said CLAP HERE with arrows; Rafi took the signs down and put them back up in places where they would be useful instead of bossy. The suit did not come but a woman with dirt under her nails did, and she told him afterwards that she had been running since she was eleven and between shifts and had never told anyone because it was hers. He gave her nothing but the nod you give a person when your secrets recognise each other.

Flo turned up one Thursday, unexpected and inevitable, with a thermos and a roll of tape she probably did sleep with under her pillow after all. She watched and did not correct even when the tape on the floor offended her tidiness. She hugged him at the end with the side of her body that is used to heavy objects and said, “I see you,” and he believed her because she is the sort of woman who tells the truth even when it is mild. Yvonne sent him stew in jars with labels she had written in capitals and then drawn flowers on for no reason except joy. Rosanna’s email about Champions grew increasingly polite and then stopped, which he appreciated because it meant someone had listened to a no that had been too carefully offered to be fun to receive.

When Leah came back between light installations and lectures about light refracting through history, her bag bumped the hall door and she kissed him like you kiss someone you have identified as home and you have come back to your own sofa. She found the hall warmer because of all the breath that had been stored in it and the ladder easier because other hands had learned to lift as if lifting were not a way to show off. He watched her look at the room like a woman asking a question of a mirror and finding the right one staring back. She looked at him and smiled in a way that could not be misread by anyone with half a heart and he understood that whatever they were building had survived this small test and now deserved the next one.

Sometimes, after everyone had left, he and Leah sat on the stage step that had bruised his knee and held mugs of tea like proof they existed in the same temperature. They talked about the places the piece could go and the places it might refuse to go, because art is particular like that. They talked about money with the professionalism of people who had learned that hope doesn’t pay for broom heads. They spoke about perhaps teaching, perhaps making a course in moving and listening for kids who had only been taught to move in straight lines. Leah told him about Glasgow’s square light finally acting like a square, and he told her about a boy in Kettering who had tried to nick the chalk and then put it back because he had started thinking of lines differently. They drew maps on the backs of leaflets as if they had invented cartography.

There was a day of snow that thickened the village in the way snow does when it decides to stay. They cancelled the showing because people broke themselves on pavements for less. Rafi ran anyway, because he always did in snow; he liked his shoes’ arrogance against its powder, and he liked the way the sky felt nearer because noise had been muffled. He saw Jim and Mavis because he always saw Jim and Mavis. Mavis had a coat that made her look like a small badly disguised sheep, and she left footprints like tiny commas. Jim told him the story of his wife’s first winter here, how she had taught him that snow was to be walked in, not complained about, and Rafi listened because sometimes you collect the details of other people’s marriages like ornaments to hang from your own future. When he got home his mother warmed him like you warm a thing you had not been sure the day would return, and his father said something about grit and duty and Rafi kissed his head without asking permission because adults did not get enough kisses and the boy inside him had learned that you don’t wait for those.

At the end of that snow day, when everyone had already put their kettles on in anticipation of a future, an email arrived from someone who had tried to write like Koine Greek and failed but had succeeded in being kind. It was from a physiotherapist, not Lo’s friend but another, a woman who had watched a clip online and thought she could help him unlearn the angle that kept making his knee cruel. She offered no miracles and a list of appointments that had hours Rafi didn’t have and a rate he could barely afford, and he wrote back yes anyway, because bodies cannot read calendars or bank statements and still have to be answered.

He slept then the sleep of someone who had learned that making things was less about being chosen and more about choosing, who had learned that ladders are about reaching but also about coming down carefully to the floor that loved you first, who had learned he was much braver in rooms with chairs than in rooms with glitter. He woke with the mist sitting on the Ouse in its old reliable pose, and he took the map of all the rooms he had visited and folded it back into his pocket because he would need the warmth. He went downstairs to find his mother spoiling the tea leaves with boiled water and his father pretending he had not got up to stir the porridge already, and he smiled at both of them with all his good teeth and said, because you have to keep saying it until it is too normal for legend, “Morning.”

Chapter 8

Anita’s clinic had no time for candles. It smelt of eucalyptus and disinfectant and an optimism so practical it put its hair up. The waiting room chairs made everyone the same height. A poster of a human knee showed a cross-section of tendons and words that were both familiar and a little comic—patella, meniscus, the Latin for a hinge pretending to be a cathedral. A delivery driver with tape on three fingers read a four-month-old cycling magazine with concentration you would not waste on scripture. An older woman with fencing scars on her forearm tied and untied her shoelace as if she could knot pain into submission. Anita came out with a clipboard and a ponytail that had given up obedience a decade ago, and when she looked at Rafi, she looked like a person measuring the distance between a problem and a solution she intended to reach.

He expected briskness and received it, but wrapped in something warmer and older, the tone of a woman whose grandmother had taught her to boil bones into broth and who now did the same for ligaments. She asked questions that insisted on whole answers and then, when he gave her half, lifted an eyebrow until the rest came. She placed her fingers on his knee with the attention of someone listening to a lea of bees. She watched how he stood, which was news to him, because he had thought standing was just what came with legs, and she taught him how the foot had been a small liar and the hip a noble idiot long before the knee had had its say. She made him step up and down on a block and laughed at the solemnity he brought to the task. “You run like a poet when you’re working,” she said, “and walk like a man who doesn’t love himself enough. Put your feet under you. Make your backside do its job. The knee is Switzerland, it only complains because the neighbours are fighting.”

The work was slow and humiliating in the way useful things are. He learned the kind of pain that asks for a chair and not a surgeon. He taped in patterns and stood on his toes brushing his teeth because Anita said that was the easiest way to remind stubborn calves they had a role. She put a metronome on his phone and told him not to chase speed yet but cadence, as if running could be taught by ticking. He lay with a band looped above his knees and opened and closed them until the muscles that did not know their own names introduced themselves. She taught him to press his big toe into the floor and felt a small but seismic change in how his arch woke, which made him feel like someone had wired a light to a circuit he had always thought was broken. When he left on the first day the ultrasound gel clung to his skin with the obstinacy of grief, and he liked it in spite of himself because persistence looked good on him and on other things that wanted to last.

On the walk home from the first appointment, the village had its hands in its pockets and its eyes on the ground, the way places do when rain has happened and they are trying to pretend it was a plan. He saw Jim in his usual spot and would have passed quietly, but Jim tapped the dog lead against his palm in a way that meant a message. “My Mavis says you’ll be good,” he said, as if the narrow-eyed terrier had a medical degree and favoured knees over bones. “She’s got a nose for these things.” Mavis looked up, snorted, and sneezed in a way that managed to be both rude and affectionate. Rafi knelt and scratched her scruff and felt the knee complain and greet him both, a domestic quarrel halfway through being resolved. He told Jim about the metronome. Jim said he’d once tried to make himself walk to the beat of the shipping forecast and had ended up buying a newspaper he did not need. They parted with the easy ritual of men who had watched each other in all seasons and found each other present.

Leah made the hall warm even before she arrived by the door; anticipation does that. She had the Glasgow light in her skin, the reflection of a square pretending not to be a square still in the backs of her eyes. She put her bag down, found the tape, looked at him, looked at his knee, and did not ask how he was, because the answer would be in his gait. He showed her the homework Anita had written in a tidy script that still somehow smelt of eucalyptus, and she read it like she reads scores, turning the page with a thumb as if permission had to be earned. Together, they picked apart the piece to make a nest for this new gait. They took the arrogance out of one jump and left behind something that looked like confidence instead. They stretched the pause by the noticeboard where the Tai Chi sign peeled, because the room liked it and people’s shoulders lowered when he did. Leah held the metronome and, wicked, put a beat in that felt like house music for six seconds, then returned to a more generous tick. He swore at her, loving and sincere, and she grinned, admiring and shameless.

Cambridge’s black box gave them back a version of themselves that had been waiting for a higher ceiling. The tech there did not sigh at ladders; they measured them and built a small metal safety life for each rung. The room took light like a thirsty animal. The first run read as too big, and then they taught themselves, as they had in the library, to let the piece take the volume it could use. People came with brains that had been fed by books, which makes no difference to lungs, and they inhaled at the same places as the librarian’s cousin’s town. Afterward, a man who had once published a paper about improvisation in early modern verse stood at the bar with a beer and cried without noise, and then said, too loudly, “Well done,” as if he needed to turn feeling into examination to keep standing. A young woman with hair the colour of chestnut burrs told Leah she had been trying to write about breath for months and this would help and Leah made a sound like a tiny bird being startled into life.

Money was a list that grew teeth. The van drank petrol like a cousin you cannot send away from the table. Insurance wrote to ask whether any audience members were likely to attempt to climb the ladder on their own after an event and wanted to know what signage would be present if so, as if the answer could ever be truly calming. Anita’s appointments came with a price, and Rafi paid them gladly and then went to the shop to take extra shifts without calling them that, stacking tins in a row that pleased both his boss and his mother’s sense of order. He and Leah went to a meeting at the council and sat under a strip light that made everyone look ghostly. They spoke to a panel who had the air of judges at a show neither of them respected, and they did their best to be brief and persuasive without performing gratitude as if mending a shirt in public. An old councillor with ears like surprised paper said the ladder worried him, and Leah said softly that they could do it without the ladder if that was what the room needed, and he looked disappointed, as if he had wanted to be the sort of man who had forbidden something and been resisted, and Rafi felt almost sorry for his thwarted heroics.

Kaia’s calls now came with the background noise of other people’s lives. She would be whispering in a stairwell while a poet refused to go on second because of a superstition about sevens. She would be stirring something that clinked against enamel. She would be shepherding volunteers into a confidence about their own thresholds. Her festival of small and intense things had grown in a manner that made her laugh and also list, and she sent them to a mill that had decided to be a community centre and to a school where the caretaker had the keys to every door ever manufactured and a face like a walnut. In one city the power failed three minutes after Rafi began. There was a small, wet collective gasp because English buildings are afraid of their own darkness. Flo would have shouted solutions and sent people running for gels and batteries; here there was only Kaia with a torch she had grabbed out of her bag and a child whose mother had taught them to carry a torch always because it made you useful in winter. Kaia handed the light to the child with strict instructions and the child shone it like a blessing. Rafi looked up and found a room that had decided to go with him anyway. He took the piece down to its skeleton. He counted out loud when he would have breathed silently. He let his foot fall make the beat. He made shadow into another body. People leaned forward in their chairs as if they were at the side of a lane and the runner had appeared suddenly and would disappear if their eyes wandered. Someone at the back whispered “listen,” and the room obeyed. When the lights came back, no one clapped immediately; they stood instead, and the applause, when it arrived, felt less like noise than like a building starting its own heart.

The boy who had thrown his jacket at Peterborough turned up in Kettering without announcing himself and stood at the side, near the exit, as if he wanted to practise leaving. He had cut his hair not because he had been told to but because something had bored him. He had the slant of a boy who tries to become smaller while still demanding to be seen. He watched and then did not disappear. He hung around the boxes afterward with the air of a person casing a joint and then asked Leah whether she needed hands, which even he knew was a ridiculous question. She put gaffer tape strips on his palms in an initiation that had no ceremony and told him to pull when she said pull. He did pull and did not drop anything and at one point looked at the ladder with such hunger that Rafi thought of himself at fifteen wanting a line on a track to move just so. They found out his name was Ty because Akan names have travelled and then became English without asking permission and because he said, awkward, “It’s Tyler, but no one calls me that except my nan.” He started coming Tuesdays and Thursdays and brought a friend once who laughed until his hoodie shook and then and then quietly came back Thursday without the hoodie. When Ty wasn’t there, Rafi felt the gap and did not admit it because men can be stubborn for no good reason.

Rafi’s father approached the problem of decisions as if it were a cupboard to be built, with shelves and screws and instructions that had been translated twice. He kept the notebook Maya had insisted on, a fat thing with an elastic that bit and pages that smelled of new. He wrote down numbers in the tidy hand he had saved for cheques and thank-you cards and words he did not want anyone to misread. He presented Rafi with one possibility a week as agreed and took rejection with a mouth that did not sulk but knew how. He also, in the third week of Anita’s plan, did something uncharacteristic. He put on trainers that belonged more to dog walking than exertion and stood at the bottom of the stairs as if calling a taxi. “Come,” he said, and Rafi, who was not sure which of them was being called, put his own shoes back on. They walked first because you do not take a village man into running like dragging takes a suitcase back from a holiday. They walked to the bridge and then to the halfway mark of the unfinished hedge. They shared a look that stood for permission without godmothers. His father trotted then, and Rafi saw his father’s body turn back into a body he knew from photographs, and a shock of tenderness went through him so quickly he missed two whole breaths. The older man ran like a caravan setting off, steady because there was nowhere else to be. He lasted longer than either of them would have predicted and then pretended he had only meant to go that far. When he stopped, he did not wheeze; he laughed. “Dog will outrun me,” he said about a dog he did not own, and Rafi said, useless and whole, “Good.”

The letter from Champions came one more time, very polite, with a subject line that had learned to emulate human. It offered verticality again—silk, rigs, the magic of professional harnessing—and name-checked a singer whom Rafi had never heard but whose face he had seen twenty times on the co-op magazines because people with hair like that must have a quote next to their jaw. It offered a fee that would pay Anita and the van and the ladder’s stiffening and new gaffer tape until kingdom come. It promised that this time they understood his ethos and would let the piece speak as it wanted to speak and would only ask that he not wear “muted tones” because the camera loved him more if he did not try to pretend he was a pavement. He sat with the email and then went to the hall and turned on the big lights and sat on the floor with his back to the stage and his knees up because Anita would have told him off if he had flattened them. He watched the dust perform its ballet in the gold air. He put the email on loud in his head and listened to how the words crashed into the ribs of the room. He read it to Leah and to Maya and then to himself in the mirror in the staff toilet at the shop because that had been his rehearsal space for shock before and could be again. In the end he wrote an answer that was a thank you and a no and a plan all at once. He wrote that he had found where the piece fit and it was in rooms where people breathed each other into being. He wrote that if the show ever wanted to point a camera at a library without asking it to be purple, they could call him. He pressed send and felt that particular mix of relief and fear that comes when you have taken water away from a plant and asked it to grow stronger roots. He told his father with the respect of a man who had once thrown a door shut and regretted the echo for years. His father looked at him, then at the ledger of his own hopes, then at his wife stirring dal, and nodded like a man signing a treaty that might yet be worth the ink.

The physiotherapist’s work stitched itself into everything. He found himself standing better when he poured tea and could feel when he slouched to please other people’s discomfort, which was a fascinating discovery because he had not known posture could be politeness. He felt the metronome when he chopped onions, which turned dinner into a practice that Leah found both admirable and infuriating, because no one wants to marry a man who taps when you are trying not to burn garlic. He started sitting on the hall floor with kids while talking about breath because sitting on chairs had made him the wrong height for listening. Ty, who was eighteen if you added kindness and mischief like tax, asked Anita to show him how to tape an ankle because a boy on his estate had twisted something that would become two weeks of bed without help, and Anita taught him, and Ty did it, and that boy somewhere lay with his ankle neat and his pride held together by a grid of pink.

Spring arrived suddenly like a dinner guest you had forgotten to expect and instantly forgave for being early. The river lost its shoulders. The lane sprouted dandelions like exclamation marks. The birds had a union meeting and decided in favour of ridiculous noise. Leah’s residency ended for a time and she returned with a new way of looking at everything a bright rectangle could hover over. She taught Rafi to place a lamp so it found his shoe and made the smallest step look like a sentence he meant. He taught her to breathe in counts of easy, medium, hard, because everything was training if you named it clearly. They began to allow themselves to make future in sentences longer than one clause. They spoke about a week in June where they would do four halls in four towns and call it a tour because no one else would, and a month in September where they would do fewer rooms and thicker conversations with kids who believed shoulders were for armour. Maya, practical as always, began hoarding Tupperware. Rafi’s father sourced a second-hand trolley for the ladder that would not lose a wheel on cobbles, and a man in the hardware who had refused to give him discount for a decade suddenly did and said it was about community and not because Rafi had been on the television, which made everyone smile as if they had forgotten to do it earlier.

They began taking other people’s stories on purpose. After a showing, they put a paper on the table and wrote, breathe here, and left a pen. People began to leave words like seeds you press into soil with one finger. “First run, after chemo.” “I ran away from him and toward something else.” “I am seventy-one and my left foot thinks it is twenty; I let it.” “I cannot run, my hip is iron, but I stand and breathe at your pause and I am moving there.” The paper filled and they replaced it and that filled too, and they realised they were collecting a map that belonged to everyone. Kaia cried when she saw it and then stopped because she had pies in the oven for a fundraiser and human bodies must also eat. Mr. Dalton sent a photo of his cousin standing by a sign that said please keep quiet seated quietly next to a boy in a football shirt who was telling him a story and Mr. Dalton had written, patient in biro, you have turned my library loud and I can bear it.

One afternoon the river rose without drama, a slow, serious rising that made people frown at the sky for doing its job. The embankment took a small drink and then took more, and by morning the path knew the river too well. Rafi went to run and found himself at a new edge. He stood there like a child at a grown-up’s party, hands in pockets, information his. Jim and Mavis arrived with the authority of regulars. They all looked at the water. Mavis regarded a floating twig as if it owed her money. Jim said they would give the river an hour and it would give them back the path, and Rafi thought how much of his new life had been like this—waiting for something bigger than him to decide to recede. He did not run. He walked the long way round past houses he usually ignored and saw a boy who might have been Ty’s brother teach a younger child to skip rope, and the rope licked the pavement like flame and no one got hurt. When he got home he had been walking long enough that his body had forgotten to want more, and he put the kettle on and found the metronome still ticking in his pocket and turned it off and did not feel guilty.

They took the piece to a prison because Kaia knew a man who knew a man who trusted her more than he trusted any email, and one day the ladder passed through a metal detector and the boxes got sniffed and Leah had to explain gaffer tape as if it were contraband mana. The men in the room had shoulders that had learned curriculum other rooms do not teach. The air smelt of bleach and longing. An officer with kind wrists told Rafi quietly which corners not to stand in and then stood near them anyway so he wouldn’t have to be brave about it. Rafi did not make jokes about running. He ran small. He spoke the counts out loud because the room did not trust silence yet. He paused and felt the pause be the most dangerous and tender thing in the building. One man at the back stood abruptly and then sat again because he remembered rules about standing and not standing and his eyes were wet in the way eyes get when you are furious at them for betraying you. After, a man with tattoos like a family turned his palms up in a gesture older than laws and asked if it counted as running if you walked fast enough to forget your name. Rafi said, “Yes.” Later, back home, when Maya asked him in the cautious way she reserved for new theatres whether it had gone all right, he said, “Yes,” and meant yes in twenty directions.

There were arguments that did not blow walls down. He and Leah learned how to disagree about where a light should go without making the room colder. He and his father learned how to argue about agents without suggesting that love was conditional. Maya argued with a council person who had said the hall should raise its hire fee for “professional work” and she asked archly how the village would measure professionalism in a place that smelt of sponge cake and chalk, and the fee remained the same. He and Anita argued with his knee about how quickly it should trust and won some weeks and lost some. He and his body began to speak to each other less like enemies and more like business partners who admired each other’s luck.

On a day when nothing remarkable happened—no invitations, no money, no crisis, the best—he walked to the allotments to borrow a spade for a thing that would later be called a set element and then, after it failed to look like anything except a spade, would be called a spade. He saw a notice about a summer fair in letters that had been painted by someone whose handwriting had an accent. He watched an old man and a younger woman argue delicately about compost and need and kindness. He stopped by the butcher where the man behind the counter always called him “son” in a tone that meant neither power nor possession, and he bought sausages because the body must have sausages sometimes even if it has an ethos and a metronome. He took them home and his mother pretended not to be delighted and then did that thing she did with onions that made summer meals taste like rain had never been invented.

He slept well that night. He dreamed of ladders that rose without permission and of floors that offered themselves like hosts. He woke to a morning that smelt of cut grass and toast and Maya’s shampoo and the faint ghost of Yvonne’s turmeric in a jar in the fridge. He ran a small loop because Anita had said he could and because his feet had made a contract with the Ouse as binding as a court makes. He saw Ty on the path with a friend and they pretended not to see each other until they had to, and then Ty asked about the prison in a way that made it clear he was asking about himself. He answered like a man who believed breath had to be earned, every day, willingly. He came home and the kettle sang the way kettles sing when mornings have been trained to be kind.

There would be other calls and letters and injuries and lifts in borrowed vans that rattled with ladders and resolve. There would be halls that smelt of bleach and hope and halls that smelt only of polish and biscuits. There would be nights when the metronome kept time without him and days when he left his phone in the drawer and suffered only the mild itch of missing everyone who had ever wanted anything from him. There would be a time, not far, when Leah would say “we need to decide if we are the kind of people who ask for money in advance,” and they would try and not be bad at it. There would be, tomorrow, Anita reminding him that glutes are destiny and him pretending to be scandalised. There was, now, his mother with a crossword and his father with a fixed door and a pen that still had ink in it. There was the Ouse with its steam like second weather and the village with its curtains adjusting their familiarity. There was the piece, which was no longer a thing he had carried alone but a thing that had learned to be carried and had opinions about where it should go next. He put bread in the toaster and listened for the pop and found himself on the exact beat, and when he laughed, he tested his knee by accident, and the knee laughed too.

Chapter 9

By June the air had learned to be warm without apologising. Brampton unpacked its summer in small confident gestures: washing lines strung like bunting between converted semis, a smell of cut grass that had the nerve to be nostalgic while it was still being made, children riding bikes in pairs as if physics preferred company. The summer fair appointed the recreation ground as its temporary capital. Men you only ever saw at funerals and fêtes hauled trestle tables into rows, arguing gently about right angles and gravy. The WI’s Victoria sponges sat with the patient hauteur of queens who know they can be decapitated by a knife and still be adored. The brass band warmed up by trying out bits of four different songs at once, which in aggregate sounded like a factory testing itself; then, as if shamed by cacophony, they found a chord and the field turned its head.

Leah had drawn a little diagram of the grass like a general planning an invasion and found a corner that would not interfere with the hoopla or the ferret racing. The ladder arrived under a tarpaulin to preserve what dignity a ladder can in public and Rafi’s father arranged stakes as if he were pitching their tent on the moon. Ty and two of his friends had been persuaded into volunteer tee-shirts that made them look like they had been captured by an optimistic charity. They worked fast in the way boys do when work becomes game; one of them—Joel, who had hair he had to keep adjusting because it had ideas of its own—took possession of the gaffer tape with missionary zeal. Leah checked the sightlines, looked at the brass, looked at the clouds; she sniffed for rain and rehearsed the speech she would give it if it came. Maya had secured the tea tent under a marshalling system that would have fed an army without visible leadership and stood in the shade counting cups as if each were a tiny hymn.

Rafi walked the piece slowly, as he always did in new spaces, his feet writing letters the grass tried to forget immediately. Anita, who had accepted a slice of lemon drizzle as payment for three men telling her elaborate stories about their knees while she tried to drink her tea, watched him from under a hat borrowed from someone who had been to Goa once and kept a hat to prove it. She had signed off on his return to short runs, and he had been faithful to the metronome when he found it helpful and ignored it when he needed to feel human rather than measured. His father had fallen into the habit, one he tried and failed to make seem accidental, of coming for five minutes when Rafi set up and staying for forty, loitering near the ladder like a man pretending he didn’t know his son would one day climb things with grace.

Of course bunting attempted assassination. Leah had thought she had calculated wind, but bunting, like gossip, finds a draft. At the second run-through a burst of instructional jazz from the band sent a gust along the edge of a wonky gazebo; the string of flags wagged like a warning and then went possessive, wrapping one coloured mouth around the ladder’s third rung. Ty lunged without thinking, Joel grabbed Ty’s shirt to keep him a person rather than a story, and for a second Rafi saw ten possible outcomes and chose, by luck and Anita’s insistence on midfoot, the one where no one’s head met metal. The ladder rang, the flags unlooped in a fit of conscience, and everyone laughed the laugh human throats make to persuade bodies to be calmer than they deserve. The band, oblivious in a way that made Rafi 60% envious and 40% homicidal, completed their phrase and someone cried, “Encore,” in a voice made partly of beer.

When he did the piece for the crowd, he did it stripped of the elements that pretended to be magic. It had no fog and less light and still managed to feel like a secret being told by a friend. The audience was a collection of neighbours who had chosen to stand in the sun for longer than was sensible. Babies dozed with their mouths lightly open like held musical notes. Teenagers pretended to be bored and staged their boredom six feet closer than usual. Jim was there, of course, Mavis leashed, the two of them looking as if the day had been invented to give them something to notice. When the ladder rose, the band, perhaps without meaning to, found the chord they’d been reaching for all afternoon and the moment stowed itself away in people’s bodies for later. Afterwards Rafi found grass stuck to his calf and an odd sense that he had been in a room with no walls; he wiped at the grass and told his father without looking, “I didn’t fall,” and his father said, “No one asked you to jump,” and then, almost at the same time, they both smiled like men who had shared a joke they would not waste by saying aloud too much.

At the stall where honesty boxes did brisk trade and dishonesty had the day off, an old coach from Loughborough approached with a hesitancy that either age or memory had given him. It wasn’t Lo. It was the other one, from a year when Rafi had come to a track with numbers in his head and had left with the numbers redrawn. The man still had a stopwatch on his wrist like a stubborn watchman. He said Rafi’s name with a question mark and then explained who he had been in case time had scrubbed the chalk lines of hierarchy from both their minds. He did not apologise. Men like him rarely apologise; they make observations and hope you will read the apology there. He said, “You found your way,” and then, because he could not resist categorisation even now, asked, “Do you think you’re happy?” Rafi had been prepared for judgement or a story that returned the old man to the centre of the lane. He had not been prepared for a question that had managed to shed most of its self-interest. He answered simply, because there are times to be plain. “More than I thought I would be when I was twenty-one,” he said. The man nodded once, sharp, like a pencil being set against paper, and went to buy a slice of Battenberg as if sugar could move blood where apology would not go.

Leah had been offered a commission before the fair, and it had sat in her bag all morning like a folded bird. A dance company in Leeds wanted a design for a piece about women and patience. They had said the words budget and time frame like people who were careful and brave, and Leah had spent an hour composing an email that would make it clear she was not going to be the kind of designer who tolerated purple unless it had earned it. Rafi found her behind the coconut shy peering at her phone with the intensity that suggests both delight and the start of trouble. She told him at once because she had learned, from months and a kitchen table, that the work only grew well if it was said out loud early. He said the thing he had had to learn to say when his bones insisted he protect himself from loss: “Yes,” he said. “Do it. We’ll grow the other bit like we’ve been growing it: with tea and cardboard and other people’s rooms. We can be both.” The coconut shy man overheard and shouted, “Both!” at the exact moment someone knocked a coconut into the grass and the stall let out a whoop that passed for approval.

Practicality followed them home like a good-natured dog. They sat at the kitchen table and agreed, between porridge and emails and Maya’s list of what could be frozen, that they would make themselves into a structure other people could understand and give money to. A very nice man at the council had used the letters C and I and C in a particular order and handed them a leaflet that smelled of seriousness. Community interest looked good on them; it was the description they had been fumbling for when asked, on forms that welcomed verbs and then punished their use, what they were for. They wrote a name down that made them both grin and then hesitate in case names were fragile. Leah tested Breath & Ladder out loud and the room did not object; Rafi tried Lanes & Ladders and hated the sibilance; Maya said she liked Ouse Right with a little laugh at her own audacity; in the end, because it was exactly halfway between earnest and silly, they chose Small Rooms Company and added, in small letters, and Wide Breaths so that the people who had been at the library would feel recognised. His father drew up a budget on squared paper like a man planning to tile, and when they told him he could be a director if he liked, he declined and then accepted because the word director sounded like a chair and he had always wanted to sit down for a living.

Anita added a slow 10k to his plan. The point was not the time, she said, and then put a number on the paper that was roughly his time and he pretended not to see her trick. He hated the idea of a bib pinned to his shirt and a clock playing god and he agreed anyway because the event would raise money for the hall’s new heaters and he had started to understand that personal ethos had to be porous enough to let other people in. They made it into a village thing so it would not swallow him; Jim raised his hand at a meeting in the back of the pub and volunteered to be in charge of signage, which meant that the route would be marked by bits of cardboard attached to lampposts at shoulder height for a man who had broken mass-produced measures into pieces and preferred his own. Ty and Joel ran two miles and walked one and then, without confessing it counted, ran another. Rafi’s father refused to be timed and walked with the man from the butcher, the two of them discussing the politics of mince. Maya walked the last hundred metres diagonally because she refused to be shepherded by tape and the finish line judge, who had been told her job mattered, tried to scowl at her and could not. Rafi found himself at a pace that let him see faces and road and the sky, and finished upright with his knee unmutinied and his chest warm with the ordinary human ache of doing something you could do without harm.

Kaia’s voice arrived through a phone and also, increasingly, in person with cake. The festival had outgrown its original name without noticing and was now a quilt of places and people—library corners, school halls, a skate park that insisted on being part of the arts whether anyone liked it or not. She asked Rafi and Leah if they would curate a strand. Curate sounded like a word that required hats; they said yes because what it mostly meant in Kaia’s mouth was, “Choose people you want to listen to and then make other people listen to them too.” They sat with lists and thought of a woman whose hands told jokes before her mouth did, and a man who played a hurdy-gurdy as if the machine had modern feelings, and a boy who could make mathematics on a whiteboard sound like jazz. Rafi discovered that inviting is a kind of art, and also that cancelling is too, because a mime got a gig in Spain that would pay for his sister’s operation and they had to find someone in a day who could hold quiet like water; he learned to breathe around other people’s emergencies and his own instinct to solve what should only be held.

The first proper stumble belonged to Ty. Trouble is rarely a lion; it’s a wasp you ignore until your thigh wears it. He didn’t arrive at three on a Thursday. He did not message. Leah, who had taken to assuming the best because it kept the room warmer, waited until twenty past and then sent a line that sounded like a joke and was not. Rafi’s gut did its old twist, the one that sat behind his belly button and listened for the squeal of brakes. Ty turned up Saturday with an apology that had been made brittle by another adult’s voice somewhere else. He had been stopped with a friend by a man in a store who took boys with hoods to be a pair rather than two. There had been an argument that could have been a cautionary tale and was, in the end, just an argument with a notice attached in biro to his day. He had the shaky look of a person who did not want his mouth to open because if it did it might let water out. Rafi did not give him a speech. He gave him the ladder and told him to check the bolts, an act of trust that worked on things and people both. Leah made tea like it was a ribbon you could pull through a knot. They sat late after the hall had emptied and Ty told them, skirting detail as if it were a puddle, about his nan who had not left the sofa for days when the news was bad, and about a teacher who had said his name gently once and then never again, and about the small nobility of not doing something terrible when your body is insisting that velocity is the only salve. Rafi’s father found out, because mothers and halls tell fathers the things proper pride tries to hide, and he turned up Monday morning with a toolbox and asked Ty to help him make a trolley hook fit the ladder. Ty learned to drill in a way that would not put more holes in the universe than necessary and the next time the man in the hardware gave them discount, he did it looking at Ty like they had both agreed to be surprised.

Rosanna’s email was both courteous and, as always, late. “We’re thinking of a ‘where are they now,’” she wrote, and he could hear the line producer’s chaos in the white space between her words. “If you’re willing, we’d love to point a camera at you that isn’t purple.” He would have said no if it were the old show, the one with glitter that climbed into your hair and slept there, but Rosanna came with a history of saying the right thing when no one was listening and following through anyway. He sent a list back like someone who had finally learned to use asking not as a weapon but as a sieve: the library, the hall, Anita’s clinic if she was willing, Yvonne’s canteen for the stew and the laugh, Flo if she could be coaxed off another show into daylight. Rosanna said yes to all of it in three emails he could tell had been typed while walking. The crew came with equipment that made the hall feel small and important. They filmed Rafi and Leah chalking without asking what possessed them to still use chalk. They filmed Ty choosing tape and being in the room without performing being in the room. They filmed Anita explaining knees to a camera in the exact same tone she had explained them to Rafi and the cameraman rubbed his knee afterwards without knowing why. Yvonne talked them into thirds at the table and delivered to camera a sermon on eating that made the sound man look like he had remembered his grandmother in Karachi telling him off with love. Flo stood in the doorway, taped off a square of floor because sometimes ritual needs to be literal, and spoke two sentences about safety that had four different kinds of love in them if you had a good ear.

The cut, when it aired, was decent. There were still shots of his face that made him want to punch the person who had decided to pause on that frame, but the rooms had won. The library’s silence and then its chosen noise did their work. The village hall looked like the kind of place sensible people love without saying so in case someone raises the rent. The internet did as it does—spat, sang, remembered, forgot—and in the middle of it there were messages from people who had also found breath in small rooms and would like to find it again. Maya watched with a cushion, habit not broken by familiarity. His father pretended he was doing something with screws and then laughed too loud at a joke that wasn’t one. Leah took his hand and squeezed once at the moment where the ladder rose and the camera did not add thunder, and he discovered that the simplest thing compliments can do is show up in the right amount at the right time and no more.

They took the piece to the river that month because it had been asking. The council approved it with a paragraph about safety that made Leah grateful and Rafi smug. They chose dusk because some things should not be attempted at noon. Flo came even without being paid—later she and Leah would argue in good humour about that—and put cones where cones would do more than brand a space. People arrived with jackets though it was warm, because English skin never trusts a day’s kindness. The Ouse pretended to be still the way dogs pretend. Bats stitched the sky with the neatness of small intent. The ladder, placed on the embankment this time, learned a new humility; water changes objects and asks them to become their outlines rather than their bulk. A boy no taller than the ladder’s first rung made a beeline for it because human is human, and Ty stepped in with a hand on his shoulder that was soft as a stop sign. The boy allowed himself to be turned aside and believed for a second that he had allowed it; Rafi loved them both for the negotiation. He ran along the rubber of the path and onto the grass and let the piece do what it did when space is more than room. When the ladder rose the surface of the river took a long celebratory breath and made a copy of the rung that shook a little, as if the water shared a sense of humour with the wind. Someone on the far bank whistled. Someone nearer sang one note without meaning to and then, embarrassed, stopped. It was enough.

Afterwards, Jim told him a story about his wife he had not told anyone else in this town. It involved a ladder that was not metaphorical and an argument about whether she should be allowed to paint the second storey of a house she had decided was shabby in a way that hurt her feelings. Jim had refused her, on the sensible grounds that bodies fall, and she had gone up anyway because she despised shabby more than gravity. She had not fallen. She had waved down at him triumphantly, and then a gust had reminded her that even the triumphant have to come down with steadiness, and in the coming down they had learned, in one short ragged minute, about patience together. He handed Rafi a collar then, Mavis’s first when she had been small and the world bigger, old leather softened to the point of memory. “For the back of the stage,” he said. “So you remember to go gentle even when going clever.” Rafi promised the collar a nail and the future a nod.

There were days of pure administration thick as custard. The CIC paperwork ate an afternoon and left grease on their fingers anyway. They chose a bank with less suspicion than was wise because the woman behind the counter had lashes that felt honest. Insurance asked new questions that suggested someone had sent a memo about creative risk from an office with no chairs. Leah began a spreadsheet and startled herself by loving it. Rafi learned to say invoice without grimacing and to write the words “pro bono” on a line and not feel like he had set himself on fire. The word “tour” lost its glamour and grew a spine and still felt like a word worth pushing.

On a Tuesday when the hall felt especially like a church and a shed, Leah kissed him without workshop lighting or borrowed applause. She had been moving a lamp, then stopped moving it, then forgot she had meant to find a better angle, and he was leaning against the stage in the way that meant his knee was behaving and his head was full of lists. It didn’t feel like a confession or a line in a longer piece; it felt like discovering that breath has texture in winter. They did not ruin it with questions about always. They did not write it on paper. They did what people do when the world is large and the kitchen is small—they made tea and talked about nothing for fifteen minutes and then went back to placing tape because love is rarely glamorous when it is useful.

Anita added jumps back in small rude parcels like a teacher handing back homework with a smirk. He argued his way down from five to three and she let him win because it didn’t matter and would make him obedient about something that did. The metronome, insulted, flirted with his pockets anyway. His run routes widened by half fields at a time. He found himself keeping company with a fox one morning, the animal floating along the hedgerow with that air foxes have of understanding bureaucracy and rejecting it. He ran past a man teaching a small child to fly a kite in a wind that was technically there and practically not, and the child accepted this as a triumph. He stopped on the bridge and leaned over and saw a yellow bucket lodged under the bank like proof that even plastic wanted a quiet life sometimes.

On a Thursday that smelt of rain but was not yet wet, Ty’s nan came to the hall. She had on a cardigan with bobbles and the kind of handbag every British woman seems to acquire at fifty. She had made mango pickle that would have caused a diplomatic incident if it had been shown to certain delicate palates. She gave it to Maya with instructions Maya pretended not to know already, and then she sat and watched her grandson lift a box in the right way. She said almost nothing. When she left, she patted Rafi’s hand twice in the way hands do when they are choosing thrift with their words. The next day Ty turned up early and asked, in the tone of someone trying to convince himself this question had occurred to him before he slept, “Is there a thing like this I could learn to do, like, as a job?” Rafi had been waiting for the question since he’d met him and did not show Ty the joy and panic it produced. He said, too casually, that people paid other people to make things safe and visible, that there were courses where you learned to wrangle light or ladders or people, that being the one with the tape could be a life. Leah, who had already Googled three courses and written down the open days, said, “Let’s start with shadowing. Then let’s start with emails. You don’t have to say please to anything except deadlines.”

That night, when the field behind the hall had finally been persuaded by hay-making to smell like childhood, they put on their coats and went to the embankment without agreeing to. The Perseids had been promised and like all promised things in England came later than advertised. They lay on the slope like children and tried to call stars by names they would answer to. The meteor shower was less a shower and more the occasional streak that made you question whether your eye was inventing. That was fine; they had come for the excuse to look up. They talked about how long they could do small if small stayed interesting. They talked about rooms that were trying to find them and rooms they were trying to find. They talked about how many ladders a person should own and whether flares counted as pyro and Leah said yes and Rafi said no and it was not a dealbreaker. Leah’s head found his shoulder and stayed there until the damp suggested home. They stood and flicked grass from each other’s backs and made promises they did not speak, which are sometimes the only kind worth making.

They declared, the next week, a Sabbath of feet. They cancelled a showing without shame and wrote on the hall door a note explaining that rest is part of all good training plans. They put their phones in a drawer and let them sulk. They walked to the shop for milk as if the milk were in another country and found on the way three people they loved and two they avoided because even rest days must include reality. They sat in the garden with their toes out and watched the sky make a good-faith effort at blue. Maya brought out tea and pretended to forget to bring out biscuits so that they would have to come inside and talk to her for a minute. His father oiled the trolley wheels because idleness is a sin to some and a gift to others and he was not ready to join the latter.

At the end of the rest day, the kind of quiet tiredness that is different from exhaustion settled over his body like a blanket properly tucked. He lay in bed aware of the heat left by the day. Somewhere outside a fox considered bins with philosophical seriousness. He thought of the library with Mr. Dalton’s signs that had been moved and his slightly affronted face; of the prison where a man had learned that raising your hand did not always cost you; of Kaia’s kitchen where pies were made into programming; of Anita’s gel and metronome and hands that left his knee better than they had found it; of Flo’s tape like a boundary and a blessing; of Yvonne’s jars with their labels like small graffiti on a generous wall; of the river making a mirror for his risk and being kind about it. He thought about the scribbled paper where strangers had left their breath stories and realised he was becoming the keeper of other people’s little truths.

Before he slept, he wrote one sentence on the whiteboard Leah had fixed to the kitchen wall for lists and poems and rats of genius that scuttled at night. He wrote it slowly so as not to wake anything fragile. Keep it small and bright. In the morning Maya would underline it once and his father would circle the word bright with a small arrow that pointed to the window and Leah would draw a ladder so tiny you could almost climb it with a fingertip. Then the mist would come off the Ouse as if it had been invented brand new and they would lace their shoes and go to the hall where chalk made its constellations and people became brave at the same time with the same air.
